description:
I think this is my favorite place to go to for my work lunch. Reasonably priced and a good portion (not too much where I'm hungry but not too filling where I have to take leftovers back). Small family owned shop, snack and drink selection, traditional Japanese items that you can order in full and half sizes. 

Only downside is they only take cash which I don't always carry on me, but when I do you can for sure catch me here. 

My go-tos are Udon, chicken teriyaki, paired with some California rolls.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
Yo Yo's is five star within their playing field. Is this the greatest culinary experience you will have? No. 

Is this the best cheap, Japanese-inspired meal you can quickly grab in the financial district of San Francisco? 100%

Udon, soba, (non-raw) sushi, chicken teriyaki plates as well as a special spicy beef curry stew on Monday's. In and out in less than 10 mins under $10. Come often and the lovely husband and wife running the place will get to know you.
author: Joe L.

description:
Ventured here for a quick lunch with co-workers. The person in front of us seemed like a regular since she knew that they only serve the Beef Curry on Mondays. Needless to say, she sold me on getting just that!

I don't usually eat spicy food, so the curry was a little too hot for me. The flavor was good, but the spice kept building up. Also, the portion was wayyyyy too much for me to eat in one sitting, so I ate the leftovers for breakfast the next day. No regrets.

I'd love to try their other food! Menu is small, which I like so that I can make a quick decision. I was impressed with the speed at which they prepared the food. From when we got in line to when we walked out with our food, I swear it felt like 5 minutes. Don't let the length of the line fool you; it moves really quick!
author: Daisy Y.

description:
How can you not love a cute mom & shop eatery that serves halal meat at a descent price in the FiDi. This place is a three minute walk from work and although they only take cash, they have the best prices in town.

I normally only get the half order of Chicken Teriyaki with white rice thats $4.75. Brown rice is $2 extra. The half order even comes with a mini side salad. The meat is tender and seasoned well. 

The food is made with love, you get to support a small business and it doesn't break the bank.

Be sure to arrive early as the lines get long. 

Also, make sure to get the potstickers on the side for a $1.50 more. It's totally worth it. Yum!

Save some cash from over the weekend to treat yourself to this hidden gem.
author: Kam H.

description: Great value! I paid $10.50 for a california roll, udon with seaweed and tofu, AND a red bean mochi. Walked out feelin like a champ. Udon is not very springy but still good. I'd definitely go back during work. Love supporting a mom and pop establishment
author: Katie W.

description:
Dining on a budget!! YOYO'S is the place to go!!! 

Not only will your meal be dirt cheap, but it'll be delicious!!! Came to yoyo's on my lunch break and it was everything I needed it to be on a busy work day. 

You walk into a small shop with only two people working. With a line out the door, you'd think you'd be waiting a while right? Nope, their service is lighting fast!!! You'll be up to the counter in no time. 

I got a small udon, edamame dumplings, and seaweed salad for only $7!!! Can't beat that. The udon was my favorite. Everything was authentic and well made. 

The people working are also so sweet, a true mom & pop shop. 

Don't forget to bring cash, they don't accept card. I'll be back!!!
author: Courtney N.

description:
Yo Yo's is a hole in the wall, only to-go, mom and pop Japanese store a little outside SF's downtown lunch circuit, with ridiculously low prices. The menu is pretty simple, udon or soba noodles, chicken teriyaki over rice and prepackaged sushi rolls, dumplings and seaweed salad. You can even get half orders of udon or soba making it even cheaper. I decided to get half an order of Udon noodles ($3.50) and also grabbed a couple of rolls from the freezer on the right ($2.75 each). Payment was cash only.

The noodles turned out to be pretty good despite their rock bottom price and the broth was not overly salty. The rolls were passable. Overall, this was not a bad meal. It does not get cheaper than this in downtown. I mean things here are even cheaper than hot-dogs off a cart. It's a good place if you are on a budget.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
Yoyos is a treasure in the financial district.  It serves tasty and cheap udon and soba and is a lovely family business who knows a lot of their customer's names and has a loyal fanbase.

I recommending putting a lot of chili pepper to get even more flavor.  You can also ask more noodles and broth on the side.  There's sometimes a line at lunch but they move through it pretty quickly.
author: Mark C.

description:
I know what you're thinking...I thought the same thing ($2.50 sushi rolls in SF uh WTF!) However I hope to prove you wrong...as they did for myself! I'm working in this area and there's not too many lunch options nearby and saw this sushi place with wonderful reviews. 

I went over at 4:15 right before they closed to pick up some quick dinner and the couple greeted me and let me know that they had a sale on the sushi. Uh sale on already low priced sushi I asked? What's wrong with it, was it days old? NO she replied, we never do that! Because they were closing for the day, they needed to get rid of all the day's sushi because they're awesome like that -- they ended up giving me like 3 free rolls even though I kept declining, but who doesn't want free good sushi? I think my order was $4 for a sushi roll and seaweed salad! Literally no excuse to not have sushi anymore because of cost, you have found your gem! Oh and I got the California avocado rolls, so good! 

I'll definitely be back and ready for some free sushi (jk, I don't expect that). Definitely recommend! 

PS -- Don't offer to give your extra sushi to a homeless guy, they're to snobby in SF (lol). The valet guys happily took it though.
author: Mahsa T.

description:
Perfect for lunch. Love their sushi and the sobe noodles. 
Very sweet owners :)
Only cash though.
author: Sarmishtha S.

description:
This is my go-to spot for friendly, CHEAP and great Japanese food! Mom and Pop shop that has been there for a very long time with the owners working every weekday and do their best to make you feel at home. 
Don't forget Cash!
author: David H.

description: Affordable, simple, and tasty spot for lunch in Jackson Square. Sushi, dumplings, soba, and more can be had for just a few dollars. I like the seaweed salad and sushi rolls for a quick snack. The chicken teriyaki is not sit down restaurant quality, but will fill you up. They recently increased the prices for the dish by 50 cents. It's still a good deal though. For $6 you can get a half order of chicken teriyaki and a side of dumplings. The soba noodles in a half serving are filling as well, though the soup has a sweeter note to it. Plan to take out your food since there's only one table inside.
author: Edwina D.

description:
Finally made it to Yo Yo's today! Half order udon with dumplings for $5.50. I don't think you can beat this anywhere in SF. Goodbye forever $15 salads! I'll shove my face in tasty Asian food instead - BTW I just finished my half order udon and I'm so satisfyingly full!

Their udon reminds me of the instant Akai Kitsune Udon, mostly because of the tempura puffs, and like in the bestest way because I heart Akai Kitsune. The broth is very flavorful and not too salty. The udon noodles are not soggy and have a good bite. The skin of the dumplings are slightly too thick for my preference, but that's me being ridiculously picky because my mama makes the most amazing dumplings. The dumpling filling tastes great and they stand up to being soaked in the broth. The owners are so cute and so friendly and they move fast like lightning. There were 4 people in front of me and I was still in and out in no time. Talk about efficiency! I'm just so happy I finally checked it out and you bet I'll be back for more!

Obviously cash only as everyone already mentioned. I also overheard from owners: Curry Beef on Mondays and Tuesdays. They smelled so yummy!
author: Nana L.

description: Beef curry served on Mondays & Tuesdays!
author: Stephanie B.

description: So delicious and cheap! I'm a vegetarian so finding veggie sushi can be a Mission sometimes but not at yoyo's! I got the Cucumber roll and half order udon for 5.75 which is a total steal. Considering coming here for lunch every day from here on out. Also FYI it's cash only!
author: Cindy B.

description: 5 stars for the price (considering the pricey FiDi/Embarcadero area). It's a to go only shop with no seats, great for worker lunch pickup. It's tasty, clean, cheap, with great quality and service (mom and pop shop). The chicken teriyaki is $7.50 for a huge portion or you can get a half size (still plenty to eat) for $4. Mon and Tues has chicken curry special which is really tasty. The udon is also solid, but not amazing. The smoked salmon sushi (and all 6 roll sushis) are $2.75 which is a steal.
author: Chuck N.

description:
The owners here were super friendly, and the store has very affordable prices. We tried the udon (half size)which was very good for four dollars. It is hard to come by affordable places to eat in the financial district of sf. However, if you're looking for a great bite to  eat, with an asian flare, then YoYo's is the place to go!

Also their son goes to UCLA. Go Bruins!
author: Darrell T.

description:
A lunch for under $6 in SF sounds ridiculous, but this place pulls it off. Yo yo's is a cash only, takeout only hole in the wall type of place with the cutest couple serving chicken teriyaki, udon, soba, and an assortment of rolls at a blistering pace during the lunch rush every week day. 

The udon is so good- $.50 extra for a TON of toppings, including tofu, fish cake, tempura flakes, and seaweed. (If I recall correctly.) The noodles are the perfect texture, the broth is super tasty, and the half portion is a LOT of food. The inari is not the best I've ever had but at $1.50 for two I can't complain. It's honestly amazing that the food yo yo's serves is so cheap, but also so good. I haven't been able to try anything else so far, but I'll definitely be returning whenever I can!
author: Jess L.

description:
Absolutely no reason why I would rate this place lower than 5 stars. I was expecting long lines during lunch time but when I arrived at 12, there was no line at all. I felt like udon today so I walked straight in and ordered the full udon order with a side of dumplings for a total of $8. Also beware that this place is CASH ONLY. 

The udon was huge for the price. I was so full finishing the entire udon and the side of dumplings. The soup was hot and the noodles still had a bite to them. The broth was surprisingly flavorful and perfect on a cold SF day like today. The little balls that you see in the soups seemed like they fried tempura batter in tiny ball form and put it on top of the soup. They were super yummy and added a really great subtle flavor to the udon. The dumplings were okay and pretty standard. Nothing special but still tasty nevertheless. 

Next time i'll probably try the hot soba and maybe a side of sushi since everything is just so darn cheap. Highly recommend coming here during lunch for an easy and quick out the door take out.
author: Eric L.

description:
Amazing option for cheap grab and go. The two owners are adorable and get your order out FAST! 

I ordered the soba (I said half, but I think he gave me a whole) with dumplings. It was fulfilling 
and absolutely delicious! 

They also have sushi, terriyaki bowls, curry, and desserts! I'll probably come back here on days when I didn't pack a work lunch.
author: Monica H.

description:
Can't beat the value here, especially for this area, where I'm lucky if I can get lunch for $10. A full order of udon is only $6 (plus an additional 50 cents if you want all the toppings on it) and it's a huge portion. I added potstickers to mine for an additional $1.50, for a filling and satisfying lunch at a grand total of $8. Crazy! You can get the potstickers either in your udon or on the side (warning: they do get quite soggy in your udon).

I might be satisfied with just a half portion of the udon next time, since I was barely able to finish the full order (and trust me I have a healthy appetite). 

Super fast and efficient taking of orders, and your food is ready instantaneously so the line moves quick. Cash-only!
author: Vivian L.

description:
$6 for some delicious udon? I am in!

Came here for lunch on a rainy day, service is super fast and the place is so cute! It's a mom and pop little place. Everything is super cheap. I got the large udon with everything on it just for $6 and if you want a small it is half the price. They also have saba, chicken and rice, sushi, potstickers and so forth. Knocking off one star cause the soup was a bit on the sweeter side, but overall solid, cheap, fast and satisfying!
author: Natalie L.

description:
Mom and pop shop with literally a man and his wife working. The menu is limited with udon, soba, rice or sushi. 

It's the most affordable place I can find in the financial district. Is it the best udon? Nope. Is it the best sushi? Definitely not. But it's one of the fastest moving lunch line I've ever seen. The man takes the order and the wife makes it. Just watching her speed of fulfilling the order is enough to make me want to go again. The half order is $3.50 and full is $6. Where can you find that? Sushi is out of a fridge and you get what you paid for. Cash only. Check it out if you're on a budget.
author: Julie V.

description: I love Yo Yo's!! I've only been there a few times, but if I'm in the area and it's a cool day in SF, you'll find me here getting the udon with dumplings - yum! The couple there is so friendly! The food is so filing and reasonably priced for my budget. There is one table with a couple seats, otherwise you can walk to Levi Plaza or the park next to the TransAmerica Building to eat. Go at an "off" time to avoid the lunch line.
author: Maile N.

description: this is some very delicious UDON especially with all the fixings. Sushi was only so-so.  Service is quick so be ready. Udon is sometimes on the saltier side.
author: Taras B.

description: Don't have anything huge to add that other reviewers haven't covered, but I'm a fan! This little joint is run by an adorable, polite, hard-working, and efficient pair. The food is tasty and very reasonably priced. I love that everything is in small portions, or available in half portions, allowing you to piece together whatever you want for a meal.
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Quick, cheap, mom and pop take out place for lunch! Yoyo's is a small shop good for a quick take-out meal if you are looking for lunch to bring back to your office .If you are looking for quality ingredients in your food, this may not the place for you.

The line may look long only because a couple of people can fit inside the store. It moves super fast. The gentleman usually takes your order while the lady in the back is hastily packing your order. You will be in and out within minutes!

They serve quick Japanese food such as udon, soba, gyoza, chicken and sushi. Simple but delicious!
author: Allie Y.

description: The owner is awesome. She genuinely cares that people enjoys her food and service. Came right at closing time and she was happy to serve us and did an amazing job. Food is cheap and delicious. Seriously amazing staff. Coming back for sure on lunch break.
author: Shea Y.

description:
My go-to for a CHEAP lunch near work! Seriously, anywhere in Fidi is so expensive that it's a rare gem to find something that's decently price or dare I say, inexpensive. Yo-yo's is a mom and pop hole in the wall. Seriously the old Asian couple who owns and manages this shop are actual goals. So cute and friendly with a smile always. Everything is to-go as there is no space inside this little shop. 

There is essentially two things on the menu: noodles (udon or soba) or chicken teriyaki. Want anything else? They probably don't have it. What they lack in variety, they make up for in consistency and price. Another really nice thing is that they have half sizes for both menu items. Meaning that if you're not a heavy eater, you can pay for a half container. How great is that!

My only gripe is that it's cash only. I would eat here way more often if this wasn't the case but beggars can't be choosers for a place this reasonably price!
author: Michelle B.

description: The fact this place exists is amazing and we should all be grateful for it. Phenomenal food (get the Udon with dumplings) at ridiculously low prices made by two of the nicest people on the planet at warp speed. I once saw a sign at a different restaurant that said "fast food, good food, cheap food...pick two." This is the only place on Earth I can find where you get all three. If you say something bad about this place, you're dead to me. :)
author: Robert M.

description:
Cheap, fast, reasonable portions, friendly service, cash only. Can't ask for much more at lunch in FiDi. Definitely coming back. 

for ~$11, here's what i got:
- 1/2 order chicken teriyaki w/brown rice: a bit sweet, but good portions. would ask for less sauce next time
- california roll: $2.75/6 pieces, kani w/o mayo? thank goodness.
- 1/2 order soba: lots of seaweed, and a good amount of soba. tasty typical udon broth


tips:
- cash only
- no seating 
- line moves astonishingly quickly
author: Kristie C.

description:
I love my lunch here! I found out about this place from my co-worker. The line was kinda long but moved fast. Everything is cash ONLY. The couple running the joint is super friendly.

For $5 flat I got a half order of chicken teriyaki, brown rice, side salad and a slice of orange. The meal made me full, but not uncomfortably so. For big eaters: they have sushi rolls, udon, seaweed salad, dumplings, etc. I haven't tried them so will be back. Homecooked food, friendly couple and sub-$10 price point...I can't believe you can still get this is SF. We need more down-to-earth, budget-friendly lunch places like this!
author: Jae Tea L.

description: My mom started taking me here 10 years ago. Now I work around the corner and it is my go-to cheap lunch spot. Nice family biz!
author: M C.

description: Great value in the waterfront area. In an area with tons of expensive eateries it refreshing to find this cheap to go joint.  Chicken teriyaki was filling and I will get the dumplings next time.  Note the staff moves along the line quickly. A good lunch spot.
author: Robert C.

description:
One of the BEST customer services I have ever received the past 20 years at least.  

NOTE:  Yo Yo's accepts CASH ONLY. 

I had taste for Udon noodle today, so I went on Yelp to find an Udon place just to satisfy my craving, and somewhere close to my work.  I found Yo Yo's, 

I ordered a full Udon bowl with all toppings and 6-piece California rolls.  The total came out under $10!!!  

I am Japanese, and grew up with many different kinds of Udon, so I know what's good.  I enjoyed Yo Yo's Udon.  It had lots of seaweed and tenkasu (tempura like), and fried tofu (kitsune) was very, very good.  Noodles can be better, but with the price, it's most decent.

I have probably seen this lady owner's kind of customer services back in the 70's or 80's, but definitely not in 2018.  I do not want to go into details of what she did for me today because my intention is not to advertise their kindness for some bad people to take advantage of these good people.  All I want to say is that there are these kind of nice people like Yo Yo's still exist.  

And, Yo Yo's prices are humbly and amazingly reasonable and affordable unlike other places in the Financial District.

I will definitely go back to Yo Yo's and will try out the Soba noodle next time!
author: A I.

description: This place is soooo legit!! They have all the right things: simplicity, cost and great service. It looked like it was two people working there a mom & a pop literally. These two kind folks are what sold the place for me me. While they were talking to me they asked about me, who I was, where I came from and what I did. We had a very pleasant conversation and I would definitely love to come back again. If you're looking for a quick, easy, cheap, good bite while supporting a local family run establishment stop here!!
author: Navdeep D.

description:
Let me just start by saying that this spot is awesome! Pretty much everyone in the reviews already mentioned the same: fast, cheap and good. 

For the quantity, quality and price that they offer for their food, you truly can't ask for anything better, okay maybe you can but you get the point. I mean come on less than $3 for 6 piece of sushi and less than $4.50 for a big portion of udon, and 1.50 for seaweed salad that is a deal. 

There are plenty of places that charges way more and it's ridiculous. I ordered the seaweed salad and udon and both was delicious. Definitely a great deal for lunch especially for those of you who are like me a Japanese cuisine lover.

Overall a great place to come for a quick, cheap and good lunch meal around the area maybe stop by the reville coffee truck in the morning too if you a coffee addict or there is a Starbucks nearby as well.
author: Christopher G.

description:
Fast. Cheap. Quick. That's all you need to know. I walked in and paid and got my food in less than a minute. 

Couples run the store and the lady asked me what I wanted while the person in front of me paid. Super efficient and she quickly boils the noodles. The noodles come with seaweed, tofu skin, and tempura flakes. It's a simple meal with a nice dashi broth. 

I also got the CA roll and it isn't like restaurant quality but half decent. It's not diced up with imitation crab but they put a whole piece of it with avocado. 

I'll definitely come back again and get the half order instead. The full order is way too much for me.
author: Sarah I.

description:
This mom n' pop tiny-hole-in-a-wall-food-to-go shop serves up cheap Japanese comfort food!  They have cheap udon, cali rolls and chicken teriyaki bowls.  What a great treat for the lunchtime bunch.  

Cash Only.
author: Jenny T.

description:
A small hole in the wall place run by a very nice couple. Almost missed this place as I was trying to find it as they didn't have a sign on their windows with their name on it. 

It took 5 min to walk here from my office. I was in the store, waited in line, ordered my food, got my food and was out of the store in even less time than it took me to walk there! Very impressed with the fast service!! 

I ordered a large udon with everything (tofu, seaweed, tempura bits, and a slice of fishcake). The broth was hot and tasted good, but salty. By the end of my meal, I had to drink a cup of water. Udon was cooked perfectly. When my order was ready, the man at the register asked if I would like chili powder and I said yes. So I added the desired amount chili to the container. I expected to put the cap on the container of udon myself, but he did it for me and then bagged my meal and handed it to me! Was very surprised as I am used to places having me bag my own food at these grab-and-go type of places. 

The prices were very inexpensive, especially for being located in the financial district. Whole meal costed less than 10 dollars! The service has definitely got me coming back for sure!
author: Cynthia T.

description:
I loveee their udon. I don't come here often but when I do, they don't disappoint. Well, except for the sushi. I tried them two times on separate occasions and I definitely don't recommend it. But their salads are nice. I like the orange colored one, I think it's a seafood or squid salad? Their prices are quite cheap however it's a small store so there isn't any place to sit. But it's all good because there's a park about a block or two down from it with places to sit. 

Another down side is how they are often closed during holidays. For example, for Easter?! And two days... This is the only reason why I don't come here too frequently. Overall, their delicious udon makes up for it though.
author: Finn S.

description:
10.03.16

This place is legit. Imagine the soup nazi efficiency with no frills and quick service, but the warmth of a mom and pop shop. I don't think they'd yell at you for taking a few extra seconds to decide on what you want.

The menu is simple: chicken teriyaki, udon, or soba noodles. Limited toppings. Item of the day. Pre-packed sushi and appetizers.

Cash only.

https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yo-yos-san-francisco?select=5yXG1s2YzS7iZYz1eHn-Sw&userid=tGgTIueZy1JNTzQD9rkZLQ

Total damage for the udon with everything: $6.50
author: Jenny L.

description:
Most of the reviews are pretty accurate. The food is alright, but the couple is very endearing. They're welcoming and try to keep in touch with their clientele.

I usually get the chicken teriyaki with a side of wakame. The chicken is mass produced and service is efficient and fast. Great place to grab lunch if you're in a rush! I wished that the teriyaki chicken was grilled.
author: James N.

description:
This place is literally a mom and pop shop. 

Reasons why it's great: 

1) It's actually fast to get food here. 

2) You get a lot for your money. For $8 you're living large with udon, seaweed, fishcakes, sweet tofu and dumplings!

3) Good food, good amount, for a low price. I'm stuffed after eating everything which is a nice feeling because I don't want to be starving later and spending more money.

4) They are nice people who actually know the names of a lot of their customers. How rare is that? The answer is rare. 

5) There are other options (that I have yet to try) and still at a low price!

Not too sure why there are people saying, oh I wish they seared the teriyaki chicken, or the sauce is too sweet, or the quality -- there are two people: a mom and a pop, who are just trying to make it out, give them a break. The food is good and they have a huge customer base and so it speaks for itself. 

Also people on Yelp take themselves too seriously and think they are part-time food critiques. 

Go to Yoyo's for some quick eats at a nice price!
author: Colette K.

description: Eating on a budget in the city can be a struggle. However, Yo Yo's makes getting lunch outside so affordable! I ordered a 9 piece avocado roll and a slice of green tea cheesecake for under $5! Being vegetarian, I normally have a hard time finding vegetarian food at restaurants that serve grab-and-go food but Yo Yo's has vegetarian sushi rolls that are delicious and affordable! The service was also very quick and the owner was very nice. If you are looking for quality food for cheap, I would definitely recommend!
author: Mallika J.

description: Close to work, food is so good, and they could not be friendlier. LOVE YO YO'S!!! Go Monday or tue for some great curry rice dishes
author: Patrick B.

description: Super friendly staff that treated everyone like family and knew many of the customers by first name. Amazing noodles and wontons. Will definitely be back
author: William S.

description:
I just found my new spot for weekday lunches! 

I've been looking for new places around work to grab some lunch, and I'm so glad I ran across Yo Yo's. First of all...the prices! So cheap! I got a full size udon, 3 pieces of california roll, and 3 pieces of salmon roll all for a whopping $9.25! You just can't beat that.  I probably should have gotten a half size, but now I have dinner all ready to go! Second, the couple that owns the place is SO friendly and cute. Service is very quick and the customer service is exceptional. 

I can't wait to go back to try their soba noodles and teriyaki!
author: Gina P.

description: I liked the owners and atmosphere of this more then the food. Don't get me wrong, food was amazingly priced and decent portions. BUT the owners are the real reason to visit this place! Do you ever go home for the holidays and your home with just packed with relatives, kids running around, your mom and aunts are all in the kitchen cooking? This is what this reminds me of. It makes you feel like you're at home, this husband wife duo run this small shop, with a limited but yummy menu. They bantered between each other and the customers, which adds a little charm to SF. The line goes fairly quick, so don't get deterred by it.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Yo Yo's has great service and is SUPER cheap, but unfortunately ya get what ya pay for.

Yo Yo's is ran by the sweetest lady EVER. She's so nice and bubbly and made my coworker and I feel so welcome as we swung by during the calm after the lunch rush. I bought 6 pieces of a California roll and a big container edamame. Total: $4.25. Absolutely felt like highway robbery, but I'm not complaining.

The food, while not bad, was definitely on the bland side. The sushi wasn't flavorful unless I added the wasabi + pickled ginger, and the edamame was just plain with no salt. My taste buds were definitely a bit disappointed, albeit my wallet was happy. If you're on a budget and not picky about getting your Japanese food fix, then Yo Yo's is worth checking out.
author: Desiree S.

description: Udon noodle soup is very good. Dumplings are great. Price is reasonable and the amount is generous.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
A true mom and pop shop!

This is my favorite lunch spot to grab udon noodle soup with dumplings.  The owners are nice and serve good food!  They are also efficient, so if you see a line, it goes quickly.  Highly recommend.
author: Nancy L.

description:
Cheap lunch spot!!!   Very nice husband and wife owners!!!   Yes, there's a line but it moves quick!!!   GO HERE for cheap Japanese!!! 

And did I mentions it's CHEAP here?!?!? :P
author: Joanna R.

description: I've been on a Japanese food bender for weeks now (Ramen Underground, Shizen, Ippuku, Muracci's, etc) which could not be complete without a proper soba noodle shop and Yo Yo's is delicious and cute as hell.
author: jacob m.

description:
This is my favorite udon spot near my work!

$5.50 for a large size udon or $3 for a half order udon. The udon doesn't have any meat; instead it has fried tofu and seaweed. Simple udon, but extremely delicious!

Cash only!
author: Alice X.

description: Came again today. The sushi was good and definitely affordable! The soups remain the best thing on the menu IMO.
author: Vanessa S.

description: Top-notch, couple owned, Japanese place that was nice enough to open their doors before opening to quench my desire for sushi.  Even game a free rice since I got their squid salad and sushi.....nice peeps there..
author: Eddie D.

description:
The best udon I've ever had! For $5.50 you can get a large container of udon with all the fix ins (seaweed, tempura batter pieces, fish cake, and bean curd). The broth is sooo flavorful and the bean curd is amazing. I can literally finish the entire container soup and all.  

If you're ever in the embarcadero area you should definitely give this place a try. It is a super super tiny shop next to Starbucks and with only one small table. They also have chicken teriyaki plates, soba noodles, sushi rolls, seaweed salads, and other Japanese appetizers like edamame and gyoza. The owners are a married couple and they are just the sweetest.  You could tell they know all their customers on a personal level and always have welcoming smiles, even if you are just walking by.
author: Linz C.

description: Tasty, quick and cheap. The udon is really tasty and at a great price for lunch in SF! The couple who runs the place are super friendly. I come here 2-3 times per week for lunch. Only catch is that it's cash only.
author: Peter I.

description:
The best miso soup I've ever tested. And the best part is that it is so cheap! 
I really recommend this place!!
author: Miora R.

description: Decent place to grab a quick sushi lunch - basic rolls are fresh. They've also got dirt cheap chicken teriyaki bowls, udon, seaweed salad and dumplings served by a super duper friendly family.
author: Jane K.

description:
Just down the street from my new workplace, I have finally discovered my go-to place to eat lunch! This place seems to have regulars often, and it's no surprise once you experience the food for the first time. I got a half order of chicken teriyaki, which is $4.25. Cash only. That is INCREDIBLY inexpensive for food in FiDi... and it's a good amount too. I don't eat much, and I hate when I'm given an exorbitant amount of food at any other restaurant that I end up lugging around as leftovers, so I appreciate the option to get half orders.

You can also get noodles, sushi, seaweed salad, mochi, and a variety of other things. The food is alright but hey - for that price and quantity you had better not complain! This is also not a sit-down restaurant. Regulars probably duck out from their workplace to pick something up and head back to the office. Good fast food without tasting like horrible fast food.
author: Stefanie C.

description: Staff was MORE than friendly. Prices were inexplicably cheap for sushi. The Udon soup was fantastic too. Great place for quick, casual, cheap, and tasty food.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
CASH ONLY HERE
(don't worry, there are several ATMs around Fidi)

I felt a cold coming on and felt as though I needed some warm soup.  I ordered a regular size container of soba noodles.  My grand total?  Only $5.75.  This container is HUGE!  (See my photo)

Now, this place is not impressive by all means.  It's a tiny little convenience store that sells snacks and drinks.  There is no seating, everything is take-out.  

The noodle soup was delightful.  The broth was flavorful and complicated.  The seaweed was tasty and the noodles were tender.  What a great VALUE!

I will be back to try the sushi rolls, edamame and the udon noodle bowls for sure!
author: Andrea H.

description:
Warming family business by the SF pier!

Their food honestly taste average, but its the service and price that gives them high ratings on yelp.
You can get Japanese Soba or Udon soup for $5 or half order for $3. That is a pretty darn good deal.

Their noodle soup comes with Seaweed, tofu and beancurd skin and some tempura crumbles with shrimp flavored soup. I prefer udon over soba just because udon is chewy and it goes well with the soup. I prefer my soba cold.

Dont forget to get Seaweed salad on the side for $2.50! I promise this will be the best buy of your day if you come here for lunch! And remember CASH ONLY!

Cheers!
author: Inge C.

description:
Super affordable. Quick service. Nice couple. CASH ONLY btw! No tax included on orders. Seriously only have to wait 1 minute for your food. So wait in line!

Chicken Teriyaki was yummy. It's not EXCEPTIONALLY good but it's definitely worth the price you pay. Food is piping HOT when you get it.

Sushi is as good as it gets! Kind of tiny though...
author: Benita M.

description:
Cash only, but super cheap udon. I don't think the taste is all that to brag about, but the price-to-taste ratio makes me say that they deserve a 4 star. They also have sushi on the side which is pretty ridiculously cheap as well.

Update 5/16/17: Found out last month that they also have Soba (Buckwheat noodle) hot or cold. I was pleasantly surprised as I always enjoy eating cold soba when I'm feeling a bit sick. It was actually a bit pricey for soba, but overall it was cheaper than a regular lunch in the FIDI. Now if they can add somen to their menu, I'll be coming here on hot summer days.
author: Mike O.

description:
Actually, I would probably give this 2-2.5 stars, but I felt misled by all the positive reviews, so I'm trying to get a more accurate average.  The proprietors are definitely really, really nice, and the prices are indeed cheap.  But this is no great value, as the food is, it must be said, pretty bad.  The teriyaki is overly sweet, as is the seaweed salad.  The sushi is well below grocery store level.  The salmon roll uses cheap smoked salmon.  The california roll uses Krab with a K.  The unagi roll has an overly sweet sauce as well.  They are masking very cheap ingredients by using lots of sugar.  

If you're not sensitive to food quality at all, and want some good bulk for the dollar, this is a good choice.  Otherwise, I'd steer clear.
author: Nathan N.

description:
I've been going here for a couple months now and I've gotta say the food is pretty good. Granted, it's not the best Japanese food in San Francisco but it's definitely the cheapest. Come around 11:30 to 11:50 to get there before the lunch crowds show up.

A couple runs the place out of a little hole in the wall next to a Deli/Market and Starbucks. The prices are very reasonable and hard to beat for Japanese food in San Francisco. $2 for six rolls or $5 for nine. They also serve teriyaki chicken, wakame salad, udon, soba, salmon sushi, unagi and various drinks. The 9 piece sushi sets come in combination boxes so if you want more of one type of sushi, you gotta get there early. 

Overall, if you're looking for a quick bite to go, this is definitely a great Japanese place to go.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
They are a friendly couple, keeping the business running since 1988. I told them it was my first time there and the lady beamed at me and suggested I try the udon soup. It is a cash only place! Which was my mistake on the first visit but she let me try the udon anyway. 

I couldn't eat the udon until about an hour later but the noodles and soup were still very good. The broth is extremely savory. There's not a lot of variety of items in the soup but there is still a lot of flavor and it was only $6.60

Between the tasty udon and the friendly owners, I just had a really positive vibe from stopping by and I would definitely get udon to go again!
author: Georgia T.

description: Great and affordable food, quick service, and the "mom & pop" owners are awesome. I eat here all the time. They've met my parents. Half order of chicken teriyaki with pot stickers, please.
author: Ben S.

description: Incredibly nice people, great portion size for your buck and quick! One of my go-to lunch spots in the area.
author: Amanda W.

description:
Things I like:

1) Affordable prices!
2) Hours - open nearly all day!
3) Location

Things I don't like:

1) Lack of vegan labeling/options. They had a vegetarian rice dish, but it wasn't posted with its price in view like other dishes. It'd be easy if they had a menu and clearly labeled what was vegan or could be made vegan.

Edamame was cheap ($1.50) but not very fresh/tasty.
author: Stuart F.

description: Awesome place I found for a quick lunch.  Highly recommend the cold soba noodles which is super refreshing!!
author: Eric G.

description:
I agree with the other Yelpers. The price is reasonable, the service is friendly, and the taste is decent. You can get 1/2 order of chicken teriyaki, white rice (brown is available) and a side of salad and orange slice for under $5 and a full order is around $7.25. 

They also have soba and udon, also available in 1/2 or full order. They also offer basic rolls, nothing fancy. 

I like to mix it up sometimes and get 1/2 order chicken and 1/2 order udon for under $8 which isn't bad for the area.

There is no seating so strictly take out and they only accept cash.

I'll go maybe once every two weeks to get my YoYo's fill.
author: Scott L.

description:
My first experience with this place was back in January 2016 - my coworker brought me here - super fast, friendly, affordable (I do not want to use the word cheap!) and great authentic Asian quality!

My second experience was March 2016, where I ordered four hot soba and four cold soba; few packages of california roll - this was all for my team in SF (I am from LA). But WOW, the owners (married couple with a son who goes to UCLA so we connected well) - they are so personable! I absolutely can't wait to return to enjoy their food again. :)
author: Todd Y.

description: I come here once a week for lunch to get their delicious Udon noodle soup. The owners are very nice, their service is super fast, and the food is also cheap! The regulars are always introducing their friends and co-workers to this place.
author: Ronald F.

description: I was running errand in that area and went there and tried there lunch. The food was pretty cheap and very fast service. The lady who works there is super nice. The plus side is that they have half order option. Thus, you can try multiple items at one time. The food quality just in an average side, but they are convenient and cheap. If I were in that area again, I will definitely go back.
author: Karen X.

description:
Yes it's good but not that great. However for a quick and cheap takeout lunch, Yo Yo's will do just the trick. 

Having used to work right across the street, Yo Yo's was a dependable spot to grab some noodles in a dashi broth. On cold, wet, and foggy SF days, it really does the trick and for around $5 for the full order, it's a steal. Half orders are still sufficiently sized too if you don't have that much time for lunch. I typically add seaweed and sweet beancurd. Or "udon/soba B & C" as the sweet lady would say to me before I ordered. Yes it's really sweet that she remembers what I typically get. Not a fan of adding the tempura flakes. It gets soggy and feels extraneous. Also I get the sliced octopus salad once in a while but really don't care for the chicken teriyaki.

Here's a tip that isn't commonly known. On our rare warm days, you can get the soba noodles served cold. I like the cold noodles with the concentrated dipping sauce and some wasabi. Very refreshing. There's typically a lunchtime line but it moves fast since the lovely folks here are so efficient. And also since they can remember what you typically order.
author: Jon L.

description:
I am itching to try the udon after drooling over my friend's. Too bad I ordered a half order of chicken teriyaki  and an order of california rolls. Total costing $8. My only complaint is that the sushi rice on the california rolls taste a mushy.

There is a small line up but it goes by fast and you'll find yourself at the front of the line within a few minutes. My new Japanese "fast food" to go place.
author: Lauren K.

description: A sushi place that does sushi rice correctly, but the fillings are the cheapest substitute of the real thing.
author: Yvonne J.

description:
Love the soba. Especially on a cold SF day.
Love the wakame salad. On any given day.
Love the mochi. On days I don't watch my diet which is everyday.

I will actually travel 45 min to get food from here. The service is great. My wallet is always happy. You are always promised quick service and lovely smiles. 

FYI cash only.
author: Shruti D.

description:
There aren't much I need to say. I work in the area and this place is:
Cheap
Good
Fast. 
People are nice and they give you a decent amount of food.
author: Shirley W.

description:
I wanted a super cheap not so filling lunch & didn't have too much time on my lunch break.  I decided on trekking to Yo Yo's after reading the reviews.

Upon arrival I saw a line out the door but it moves very quickly as the sweet Asian couple running it takes your order boxes up your food & takes your money.  I decided on the half order chicken teriyaki for ($3. 75).  It comes with salad, a slice of orange & plenty of rice underneath half a chicken breast.

It tasted alright, definitely get what you pay for!  The chicken isn't grilled but had enough teriyaki sauce and was moist.  The salad was mainly lettuce & needed a little more dressing.  

I'd come back though for the cheap prices, next time I'll try the udon.  Remember everyone...*CASH ONLY!*
author: Cat C.

description:
Delicious food, awesome prices and very kind people. That's a 5 stars to me!
I discovered this place about two weeks ago and just can't stop going there for lunch.
Expect a long line starting from noon.
I guess they are husband and wife owning and working there and they are really sweet and caring. 
It is getting rare to get the combination of good food, cheap and served by very nice people. I love it!
One good thing to remember though : this is CASH ONLY!
author: Marion P.

description: Nice cheap and quick lunch for anyone working in the area. It is cash only, so make sure to prepare in advance. The soup was good quality and perfect for a rainy day. Make sure you have somewhere to take it back to since there isn't any seating in the place.
author: Jaime R.

description:
Are you looking for an affordable lunch with GOOD food in the FiDi area with a fast line? Look no further!!

I have a good 5-8 spots up my sleeves for best lunch spots in the FiDi that aren't chains, or touristy, and Yo Yo's is definitely near the top of my list. 

Ran by a very very cute asian couple, they work out of their really small shop. No seats or tables inside, that is how small we are talking. It is definitely a hole in the wall, order, pick up and move to somewhere else to grub type of place. 

Lines move fast, most of the food is already ready for pick up during lunch hours.
Don't get me wrong though, it's great food thats not "fast food" or unhealthy IMO. 

Let's get to the food.
They offer Udon, Chicken Teriyaki and sushi. Yes, it's that simple.
All udon and chicken teriyaki above have size options.
Small, or large. Large is basically double the price, and double the size. Makes sense right? 

Udon: $3.50/$6
Chicken Teriyaki: $4/$7.50

The Udon is SO delish that thinking about it is making my mouth water right now. 
The seaweed salad side is a MUST GET as well. It's only $1.50! Well worth it.

Last time I went, I spent 5 bucks. Yes, $5.00. 
I ordered the small udon and the seaweed salad. I was hungry, but this was enough to make me content. Bam. 5 bucks was MORE than worth it. 

That day, I was winning fasho. You can be a winner too, go to Yo Yo's!

Forgot to mention: Bring Cash.
author: Ben T.

description: Cheap, quick, and yummy!! Perfect lunch spot. The broth for the udon is sooo delicious. Can't go wrong with the wakame salad either! :)
author: Betty T.

description:
One of the cheapest place in the area. Totally worth the price. I got teriyaki chicken and California roll for $7. 

Only 2 seats to sit down. Ppl work in the area would come for lunch.
author: Yelp Z.

description: Had udon noodles for breakfast with chicken potstickers inside. Went right back the next day. "If you're going to San Francisco...", and you like Japanese noodles... and you like street food... this is a clean sharp spot waited by owners with friendliest attitude and manners. Enjoy.
author: Juan C.

description:
Rarely does a good idea smack you in the face! It is, however, always a great idea to come to Yo Yo's for lunch. Everything about this place warms my heart and tummy:

1) the adorable husband and wife team, friendly and incredibly endearing, taking your orders, executing your order to military precision, (if you're a regular, they'll remember your 'usual' too), and then the mad mathematician crunching your entire order total in his head. 

2) the food - delicious seaweed salad (the best I've had in California), great selection of sushi (they run out fast so come early), chicken teriyaki (awesome), and the Pièce de résistance: the udon. I can bathe in the udon broth if there's a to-go container big enough for me to fit in. I've been tempted to drink the entire container and will (intentionally and gladly) do it eventually.

3) the speed - don't fret if the line is out the door, military precision, remember? That line will shorten quickly and you'll have your opportunity for gourmet gold. With the extra time you save for your lunch hour, you can jump on Facebook or play Candy Crush. Oh, that's right, Facebook and Candy Crush is for the rest of your work day, how silly of me? =)

4) the price - you won't get quality food like this for the money they charge. My biggest appreciation is the ability to do half orders on most of these items, giving you the liberty and the tummy space to try other items without shattering your wallet. My favorite combo - half order udon, half order chicken teriyaki and seaweed salad.

I am so fortunate to work in a office that's 300 yards from this place. I'm afraid I will have to be a regular and have my 'usual' here.
author: Mike L.

description: A small hole in the wall, cash-only restaurant run by a couple. I was attracted to this place as there is always a long line outside. First time here and I ordered the udon (asked for the small but was given the large). It is really filling for one person - with broth, wonton, seaweed and noodles and just $5.50 (for the large udon). It is a bit salty however. I finished my lunch over 3 hours ago, but my throat is a little dry even with a glass of water. I would come back however and try some of their other favorites including the chicken teriyaki. Great place if you're looking to go lighter on the wallet.
author: Ananta S.

description:
Yes yes yes!!! Yo Yo's is definitely a winner in the FIDi! It's super cheap and pretty good if you're craving some soba/udon.

There are like 6 items on the menu. I always get the half soba with whatever veggie rolls look good in the front. The husband and wife are suuuuuuper fast so don't be discouraged if you see a long line outside. Once you order, you'll have your food within a minute or two.
author: Erica A.

description: Adorable owner/wife to adorable owner/husband "did you see the news about the naked Trump statue? So funny!" Besides being up to date on the latest pop culture references, this place offers comfort food at amazing value. $1.75 avocado rolls can't be beat, nor the other choices. You will realize that you have been duped your entire life into paying too much for sushi. I love how they can easily raise the prices because this is SF, but they don't. Hurrah.
author: Crystal Y.

description: I pretty much concur with the gist of the other reviews. The food is SUPER cheap! It's nice to have somewhere inexpensive to go to so near the financial district. The soba is tasty but salty, and the avocado rolls are bland without lots of soy and wasabi. You can't beat the price though!!!
author: Nasim M.

description: I work less than a block away, and this is the perfect place to get a cheap and quick lunch. I love the fact that they have half orders, so you can mix and match what you want. Super affordable and huge portions. Half order of chicken teriyaki is a decent sized meal. Adding gyoza is fairly cheap as well. Their soba hits the spot on a cold day. A lot of other asian snacks like mochi for sale too!
author: Carmen C.

description:
Hands down this is the best lunch deal in the Financial District! For ~$5, you get a big bowl of piping hot udon with seaweed, tofu, tempura pieces and fish cakes.

Whenever I need a comforting bowl of soup, Yo Yo's is first on my list. Plus, the owners are so cute - support your mom and pop shops!

Don't forget it's cash only.
author: Melissa W.

description: Can't get a better bang for your buck in the Financial District. The owners of the place are extremely friendly, and efficient. There's sometimes a pretty long line around lunch time, but it moves quick. I usually get a half order of udon, and 6 piece sushi roll. Total ends up being about $6. You can't get better than that for this area.
author: Brian K.

description:
You get what you pay for.
Mediocre good food but insanely cheap. ($5 for big bowl of noodles, or $3 for half) You can't find that price anywhere in SF.

FYI - no place to sit down and eat. You go to the counter, you order, then you leave. Food comes fast, but there is also a lunch rush. Owners' attitudes are nice.
author: Lucy C.

description: Cheap and easy california rolls, seaweed salad, and udon. Not the most intricate creations, but still tasty! Cash only
author: Mingmei N.

description: Cheap and good takeout. This place is no longer seen as über hipster, so the lines have died down and you can now get a good and cheap takeout soup without spending your whole lunch hour in line.
author: Chris N.

description: So cheap! And just what I need on a cold, foggy, SF day. I love their udon and soba noodles, but soba makes me feel a little healthier. The large size is wayyy to big for just me, so I usually get the small. Seaweed salad is great too. The owners are friendly, yet super fast.
author: Jane H.

description: I was expecting this place to be instantly amazing but it didn't quite meet my expectations. I got the full-size udon and it was really, really salty. Two water bottles later, my mouth was still really dry from all the sodium. I have not yet tried the other items on the menu, but my initial impression of this place is only worth three stars. Overall, super quick service, cheap prices, but the food quality is definitely what you pay for.
author: Sharon Y.

description:
Can't say that this is the best food I ever had but it is very decent for the price they charge.  I ordered a half order of the udon with everything and a wakame salad and the total came out to only $6. The wakame salad was super worth it ($1.50)...restaurants usually charge $4 for it. The udon came with seaweed, tofu and tempura bits. The broth was tasty and noodles were pretty good although I prefer my udon a little more chewy. 

I actually wanted to try their unagi roll but they were out when I went. Oh well, next time...

Overall a good place to grab a quick lunch to go.
author: Katelynn L.

description: Great quality for the price. Was able to get enough food for 7.5 dollars. Really recommend for people at are at Downtown.
author: Tianyu G.

description:
I can't say enough great things about Yo Yo's.  I used to work right across the street and ate there AT LEAST once a week.  My go-to order was a seaweed salad and a half order of udon, which is ONLY $5 (and CASH ONLY so be aware)!!!  Not even Subway can beat that!  I also tried their soba noodles which were delicious as well.  

It's definitely a hole-in-the-wall but you just won't find better food for the price.  Plus, you can always count on super speedy service - and with a smile!
author: Hannah C. R.

description: It's like having my own Japanese family prepare lunch for me. Joseph and Lydia are wonderful and incredibly seem to remember every customer's name. Where else can you get 9 pieces of avocado sushi, pot stickers and a banana for less than $5, served with big smiles and a chat?
author: Keith M.

description:
Yo Yo's isn't half bad.  SPEEDY service for sure, since I was in and out with hot food in less than 3 mins.  The big NO-NO was on the Udon soup.  If you can imagine soggy rice-krispies floating on top of tofu flavored like beef, J-E-L-L-O.  Gross right?  I'd like to meet the person who actually likes what I've just described because it would be a perfect rendition of my previous lunch.

Yo Yo, no no.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Super friendly couple selling the food. Hal teriyaki and half udon is perfect ( around 8 dollars in total) 
Highly recommended 
Will be back anytime soon!
author: Rudy H.

description:
Great little mom-and-pop shop. Food here is a great value- it's affordable and tastes good, perfect for lunch on the go. 

Teriyaki chicken is really good! Try it with thousand island sauce over it- I know it sounds weird but give it a try. Also try putting teriyaki sauce into the salad, its really good. The soup here is also amazing. 

Last but not least, the owners are some of the friendliest, most genuine people you'll ever meet.
author: David Y.

description:
They are located on Pacific and Sansome. They are literally a hole-in-the-wall place and it could be real easy to miss if they didn't have a line out the door and sometimes around the corner. But they move fast so it's worth the wait.

They actually remind me of that episode of Seinfeld with the soup nazi based on how they shuffle you through the line, but the only difference is that the couple that runs it are super nice!

I usually eat the udon soup which you can order half sizes or full. The half size fills me up for $3 and the full is twice that for $5. 

They also have decent chicken teriyaki for $3-6 but that's also available for half or full size. I don't want to know how big the full size is when the half fills up a big to-go box!

They also have soba, but I've never tried it, as they're known for their udon, but if it's any good as the udon, then I'm sure it's amazing!
author: Mandi W.

description:
I'll forever be loyal to Yo Yo's! It's definitely a ma & pa and they are cash only but that probably contributes to their rock-bottom prices. Have a $5 bill in your pocket? Yo Yo's will take care of you.

Their staples are definitely the Udon or Soba noodles served hot or cold. Either way is delicious. Don't be deterred by the long line, it goes really quickly. The sides are cheap but they're great for what they are. San Francisco! We can't all serve $12 sushi rolls for $2.50.... Give them a break. 

Bottom line: Get noodles. Get sides at your own risk. 

*Dear Yelpers who've left poor reviews because they didn't try the noodles, go home!*
author: Alexa A.

description:
Very nice little place with great food. Soba is superb and sushi very decent. I usually get half Soba and california roll / salmon roll and its under $8. Food is filling and tasty.
Line starts forming around noon but service is very fast. You will be in and out in less then 10 min. They have drinks, deserts, fruits and snacks. It's a great to-go place but you can also eat inside (there is 1 small table). BTW going there in few minutes :)
author: Yev K.

description:
It has lots of good reviews, but maybe I went at a bad time?

I don't think that should matter, I went at 1pm, and ordered the chicken terriyaki over brown rice. It was nothing special. The rice had absorbed all of the sauce, and the chicken was left dry, and really pink i might add. The "salad" was scraps of letteuce with thousand island sauce, and a slice of orange. I ate it because I was hungry, and the rice was not bad. It was $7.85

Will probably not be coming back here, i think i will go next door where my intention was originally.

And yes, they are cash only just FYI
author: Coraline J.

description: I can't get enough of Yoyo's. Especially in this cold weather in SF. It's perfect to warm up at lunch. The udon and chicken teriyaki are great and affordable! Basically, you're getting more than what you paid for. The customer service is fantastic as well. Looking forward to my next visit.
author: Philip L.

description:
I've only been to Yo Yo's a couple of times, but it's a great hole in the wall spot when you're in the mood for soup. You have the option of selecting either udon or soba noodles; with soba, you can order it hot or cold. The broth is rich and flavorful, and each soup is often accompanied by tempura batter flakes, bean curd, and seaweed.

My colleagues say the cold soba is actually quite good as well, but I haven't tried it yet. You can pick between a large and half sized order, which means at most you'll spend under $6. If you're into other snacks, they had sushi rolls, inari, and teriyaki on the menu as well.

Service is polite, efficient, and speedy. Cash only.
author: Johanna L.

description:
I typed "cheap lunch" into Yelp search and this is what I got.  It was indeed a cheap lunch.

Half an order of udon for $2.25 satisfied my hunger, though next time I can do without the fried crispy things that quickly turned into soggy Rice Krispies cereal.  There was also one piece of tofu, slice of fishcake, and a piece of tofu skin.  Yummy.

They were out of the smoked salmon rolls so I got the California roll.  The seaweed salad was amazingly cheap and soo good.  The bf enjoyed his full order of teriyaki chicken, which came with a small salad and two slices of oranges.  Total cost was $12.05.

There was no line at around 1:30pm, and the food is prepared and already made so there is no wait.  There is a tiny table for 1, maybe 2, so you better eat while you walk or eat in the car.

Now don't load up on the chili powder and forget to mix it into the broth before taking a sip and choke like I did.
author: Vivian H.

description: The food is great for the price. Uncommonly cheap. Will probably go regularly. Got a drink, avocado sushi roll, and a seaweed salad for 6.25!
author: Rachel R.

description:
2/8/2008 - for a cheap healthy lunch, get the Jeremy's special for $3. plenty of rice, topped with tofu, sauce, crispies, and seaweed. I don't recommend the chicken teriyaki, but the soups, udon and soba are great.
you can get meat, vegetarian or vegan dishes.

update 5/7/2012 - I love the udon full order with everything. been my fave since 2010.
author: John M.

description:
I love this little place. The service is always fast and efficient (even with long lines!), the couple who own this place are literally the sweetest people ever, and the food is consistently good.

Their soba is delicious both hot and cold. I like buying the large size for around $5, and that easily feeds me for two lunches. That's around $2.50 a meal, which is an AMAZING deal in a district where it's not unusual to pay at least $8-10. 

I think the sushi and teriyaki are ok. I don't think they're nearly as popular as the udon and soba. 

Some small notes: no seating (one tiny table only), cash only, and sometimes they put a little too much seaweed in the soup, so maybe ask for a little less.
author: Gretchen S.

description: Best prices I've seen in SF and a treat to say hello to the couple who owns the store. It makes my day saying hi to them every morning on my way to work :)
author: Kristin C.

description:
Little mom and pop shop serving up some good chicken teriyaki!  I imagine it's super convenient for people who work in the area.  Prices are cheap.  

Chicken teriyaki is bomb. (How TJ likes his chicken teriyaki: skinless dark meat = bueno, skin-on dark meat = too heavy, white meat = GTFO.) They use skinless dark meat here with a light sauce, which IMO is the best combo for teriyaki  It's too much when the sauce is so sugary and gooey that it's pretty much soy sauce jam. They don't do that here.  
They also hooked it up with this little udon soup that was great.  

Joseph and his wife are the nicest people ever.  It seemed like they knew every person that walked in while I was there, and they also remember their customer's usual orders.
author: TJ Y.

description:
Have you ever tried to find inexpensive, decent Japanese food in FiDi? Why is it so difficult? Why am I starting this review with so many questions?!

I'm surprised. I've been consistently underwhelmed. So I'm glad I found the hole-in-the-wall take out spot that is YoYo's. It's a bit of a walk from most FiDi office buildings, but it's such a nice area you won't mind it.

It's a small palce but they've got lots of options:
- Soba, udon, prepackaged sushi, and teriyaki combos (a full order is $6.50, half order is $3.75)
- Take your food and eat on on the bench outside or go to the nearby park
- Cash only
author: Mariela D.

description:
The broth is the best in the city, hands down, and the tanuki in the broth makes it so much better.

This little hole in the wall in FiDi is a true gem, and the couple that runs it couldn't be nicer or more efficient. While the noodles could be better (they fall apart a little too fast for my liking) I still love this place.
Definitely recommend the udon with everything. They also have some authentic Japanese drink options and rolls made in house.
author: Kate M.

description:
I think every review of this place talks about the following points in frequency 

1) how kind the owners are 
2) how price friendly their food is 
3) how quickly and efficiently they serve their customers 
4) how good their food is 

Well i like to make a 5th point.. 
5) They are CLEAN. 

Often times, more so than the taste or cost, i look at the way they prep and sell their food. This place is clean and meticulously kept. From few of the review, it appears this place has been in the business for a decade or more, but look inside the interior and you'd think they just open few months ago. They also cook their food every day and sell off whatever is remaining at a discount, not to keep overnight and pass it on as "Todays" goods. There's a sense of honesty and good business value which i love when i eat here. I feel that the husband and wife team enjoy what they do and they want to give a "Fair" price to their customer. Sure, they could raise a $1 for all their menu items and it would be ok, however i don't think that's their motive here. 

Today, i just picked up some half soba and avocado rolls for under $6. My co-worker on the other hand went to SBUX picked up bottle of water and sandwich of $9.... 

I say i was a winner today in lunch..
author: Youna K.

description:
I have been here several times with my friend since we both work close by. We have tried a good number of things here - sushi, inarizushi, gyoza (regular and edamame), and udon

FYI, the sushi (which is probably their weakest item in my opinion) and inarizushi (sweet tofu pouch filled with rice) are pre-prepped and packaged; they are cold and one of the items you just grab at the counter. While both type of qyoza can be bought hot or cold (cold ones on the counter, hot ones take a minute for them to pack). Lastly, the udon (served with sweet soup that is perfect if you add a little chili powder to it) is made to order and you are given the option of getting half (perfect for me) or full order. 

Anyway, it's a small shop with not much space for you to wait inside, so there is usually a line out the door, but don't be discouraged because the line moves quickly. It's the type of place where you can't be indecisive or you'll be holding up the line. The couple is really friendly and knows their regulars who like to order the same stuff. 

Although it is "Japanese takeout food" (basically you take or order what you want quickly, pay, and go), it is pretty good quality and very reasonable priced.
author: Christina L.

description:
I love this mom and pop japanese hole in the wall! You will pay less than $4 a meal! This is my go to place for comfort food when feeling under the weather. 

Remember that its cash only!

My food of choice is the half udon with both kinds of tofu and seaweed.
author: SCSR L.

description: I basically agree with the other yelpers so will just summarize my feelings (since I don't have much to add).  Super friendly people.  Great prices (especially for the FiDi district).  I've never tried the chicken teriyaki but really like their soba, udon, and seaweed salad.   The only opinion I have that contradicts the mainstream is my opinion on their sushi.  I don't care for the sushi much and would rather walk over to Safeway if cheap sushi was what I craved.  Overall, a great place to try if you work in FiDi and am looking for a tasty lunch at a decent price.
author: Linda H.

description: Awsome service and decent food. It is quite a blessing to have them near work as it is a quick pick up and grab lunch spot whenever I'm in the mood for sushi or udon noodles. The food is served hot and with the option of adding chilli powder. The owners are the sweetest people, hardworking and honest. I go to this place to support local businesses. Excellent service, price and location. I recommend Yo Yo's.
author: Fatima T.

description: This is by far one of the cheapest places you can go to for lunch in the FiDi besides McDonald's. Can't beat the price, literally. But the food is just meh... So the first time I came here I ordered the half chicken teriyaki, the sushi combo, and the seaweed salad. All were okay. I actually found a hair in my chicken teriyaki but it must have not bothered me so much because I came back a couple weeks later and bought lunch from here again. But anyway, the sushi was kinda soggy or at least the one with the sauce on it. I've also tried their udon- not bad either. This place is okay especially if you're on a budget. The food tastes like you're on a budget. The couple who works here is super sweet. And they know how to handle business. Food isn't anything to rave about.
author: Dara S.

description:
A great hole-in-the-wall in Jackson Square just north of the Financial District.

This mom & pop run establishment serves up a great soba/udon soup. I'll usually feel great for the day after having a large one with everything (+ chili powder). 

Their sushi is OK, not great. I'll usually buy some if I'm extra hungry as a filler. Their chicken teriyaki is a bit better, but the chicken is a bit fatty.

By anyways, more importantly: price is right, owners are awesome, service is quick, soup is bomb.
author: Peter M.

description:
I went here for the first time yesterday and the husband and wife team blew my mind.  I walked in,  they greeted me very nicely and then I chose my items from off the counter.  It came time to pay and I realized that they are cash only.  I only had change or credit cards.  I apologized and turned to walk out without my food and the wife asked if I work in the area, which I do. She told me to just come back and pay tomorrow. I was totally speechless. I said I'll just come back another time but she insisted. 

The sushi and seaweed salad hit the spot and you can bet I'll be back today with a payment and a very nice tip.
author: Kristy N.

description:
The beauty of Yo Yo's is its simplicity, which allows it to execute on a few items really well, really quickly. I ordered a large udon soup and salmon roll, and within 5 minutes I was back in my office, devouring the soupy goodness.

I'm no expert on udon, but the broth was excellent and the rolls were solid.
author: Chris C.

description: This place rocks. Fast, simple, inexpensive, and super friendly. I recommend their half-order of chicken teriyaki. It's the same amount of rice as the full order, just half the chicken. Other stuff that's good: California rolls, half-order hot udon, squid salad, hot chicken gyoza, and daifuku for dessert. Some food is on the counter, and you just pick what you want. Other stuff you order off the menu. If there's a line, don't worry; it moves fast. It's cash only, and there's essentially no where to sit. Instead, enjoy your Yo Yo's at Walton Square 1 block east on Pacific, or at Levi's Plaza 5 blocks north on Battery.
author: No C.

description:
this place looks a little iffy from the outside, but there is always a line. Its because the food is fast, cheap and delicious. 

I normally get the half udon and gyoza. I never walk out there spending more than 10 and thats saying something for jackson/fidi area. 

owners are a sweet couple. 

CASH ONLY!!
author: Mimi D.

description: Adorable couple runs this shop and serves up super cheap but tasty and filling udon with tofu and seaweed.  Line moves fast but cash only!
author: Jai L.

description:
I've actually come to love this place. The udon is very delicious and cheap. The sushi is okay, but it's nice to have with the udon.

The couple who owns the shop is cute and friendly. The wife and husband are always so welcoming. They are also super efficient at moving the line.
author: Margaret R.

description: A really cheap lunch option for takeout. The unagi and smokes salmon role was better than I expected considering it was  less than $3. The soba soup was fine and the full portion was pretty large. They also have udon and chicken teriyaki. A good quick fix if you want some Japanese for lunch.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Great lunch place!

Your choice of soba or udon, half or full order (brilliant concept), plus your choice of topping. They also offer daily sushi rolls, gyoza and edamame. Prices are ridiculously reasonable. It's an extremely efficient use of the small space and immaculate. This 2 person team run a tight ship keeping the line moving fast while making friendly conversation with you or their many regulars as they prepare each of the orders. 

I was a little skeptical at first but their food is good! This along with all the reasons above makes me keep coming back for more.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Since moving to the city I have been craving quality lunch time udon. Little did I know it was only two blocks away! The first time I went, I saw a little line out the door and expected good things. The soup is great, and sometimes I get a half teriyaki chicken as well so I have some protein.

The couple (?) running it are so entertaining too. Easy and Yum!
author: Mitchell S.

description:
Where else can you find a $5 lunch with plenty of varieties? Here at Yoyo's....

You can combine half orders of chicken terriyaki or hot udon or hot soba with a side of simple sushi, edamame, seaweed salad or inari (tofu skin wrapped with rice) for a total of $5.25 (total cost depends on your choices). 

They also offer full size entrees with brown rice upgrade. 

CASH ONLY!
author: Maggie C.

description:
The 2 owners that run the lil shop are great! Always with a smile and very prompt with orders. The guy is taking the orders up front and the lady is already prepping the order right behind him.  Talk about ON TOP OF IT! ahahaha 

 I come here on cold days for their udon soup.  TASTY!  There are 2 sizes available small and regular.  I get the small only because it's enough to get me warmed up and not too full.  I would definitely recommend this spot to those who crave basic Japanese cuisine (California roll, tuna roll, salmon roll, seaweed salad, chicken teriyaki, etc..).  Quick stop to fulfill that craving.  Note: They are well known for one of the best independently owned businesses (Bay Area Finds).  So stop by and you will not be disappointed.
author: Becky U.

description: Amazing chicken teriyaki for less than $5! Can't beat that out here. Cash only, but go find an ATM. Totally worth it.
author: Faisal A.

description:
Usually when I want a hot lunch I run to Walgreens and buy cup-o-noodles.  Bad, I know.  

But today I was feeling adventurous and wanted to eat a real meal, a hot one for the rainy weather.  I walked 5 blocks in the rain to Yo Yo's, and was so pleasantly surprised with my 1/2 order hot soba and 6 piece sushi.  

http://media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ORY49t4GKrF9p_fW48ST8Q/l

How cute is it that a 1/2 order comes with several sweet tofu skins (think inari sushi http://bit.ly/ij4J5F), fishcake, and tons of the dehydrated rice puffs (Korean package noodles always have these ^_^)?  The 1/2 order is very decent size, and combined with the sushi I feel so satisfied, and healthy!
author: s m.

description:
SO IMPRESSED. have not been this impressed for awhile. VERY SPECIAL PLACE!

I just got 6 salmon rolls + tofu ball + 4 edamame potstickers + seaweed salad for $6.50 and it was all DELICIOUS. 

This is the best place to pick up lunch in the Financial District.
author: Sonya Z.

description: I forgot about this hole in the wall until last week, in the area for an appointment. Always a long line during lunch hours but it is so efficient that the line moves along swiftly. Also, take out, to-go only and everything is RTE (ready to eat). I've had their udon/noodles/soup but I prefer their mini bento and small sushi. Their seaweed salad is the perfect side dish.  For $10 give or take $1 you can get a full meal with drink.
author: Mia M.

description: The owners are a really nice and generous couple. Good food and service! I ordered sushi rolls and ate there. They gave me an extra soup. Great restaurant!
author: Lilian J.

description: Quick service, cheap Japanese food. I got 6 california rolls and a seaweed salad for less than $5.
author: Jae L.

description:
Simple and tasty food with great price. 
These people are so friendly and kind and their service is super fast.
author: Esther L.

description:
It's good sushi for a incredible low price at San Francisco, the seaweed salad is the best! Workers are very friendly and nice! Enjoy this sushi with a
Seaweed salad at the top! :)
author: Jessica M.

description: Great simple udon soup and grab-and-go lunch treats (inari, seaweed salad, octopus salad). The couple that own this little shop and serve customers are so kind. Their customer service plus solid food make this a place worth putting in regular rotation.
author: Erika F.

description:
CASH ONLY. NO SEATING. DIRT CHEAP.

WIth that said, i don't think there is a cheaper place in FiDi with this much variety! Udon noodles are $2.25 and 6 Piece california roll goes for about the same price. I got those and a can of green tea for $6.00. 

The udon noodles are quite good for it being pre-made (meaning not made to order). It definitely does NOT taste like the packaged stuff bought from Asian markets. Add a little of the spice & sesame seed powder and you've got yourself a winner. "Everything" on the udon includes fried tempura bits, seaweed, fishcake, and fried tofu skin. 

The CA roll was not fantastic, but not bad either. What can you really expect for $2 something? 

Like everyone else said, the couple behind the counter is really friendly and efficient. They're also very patient because this was my first time here and i wasn't sure what to order. A small line was starting to form behind me, but they never rushed me. Thumbs up! I'll definitely be back!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Great value.  Yummy noodles as well as side dishes.  Consistent quality, consistent value.  Can be a bit of a wait during the lunch rush.
author: Jeff E.

description: The owners here have to be the nicest people working in Financial District. This is a great place to stop and get some moderately priced (some might even say cheap) and tasty udon. Don't be hesitant - just go, ask for a whole order with everything, pay your $6, and sit in the park and enjoy this amazing, beautiful place we work in. I also tried the chicken pot stickers for the first time today - $1.50 for 4 and also tasty.  Just go already.
author: Alison T.

description: A super friendly couple run this little restaurants! All the food was to go! You can get a lunch for $5, either a full size uton, or sushi with seaweed salad, or any combination you like! Cash only though.
author: Chang L.

description: I don't understand the lines and good reviews for this place. They microwave the chicken teriyaki. It was the most disgusting thing I've eaten in years. I'm sorry I usually hate leaving bad reviews but it was really gross.
author: Ron B.

description:
Cheap , easy and fast! 

I got the two 6-piece rolls (CA rolls and Smoked Salmon) and it was only $5. It tasted good but the rice was too much vinegar. 

For this amount you paid, I would not expect too much from it.
author: Liza T.

description:
As others have said, definitely worth going to given the price/quality.  It wasn't hte best food I've ever had, but it is decent and the price is right.  I ordered a half-udon with everything and got a 6 piece sushi (2 salmon, 2 CA, 2 unagi).  

I thought the sushi wasn't very good - not very flavorful.  The udon was good though, and this is coming from someone who doesn't like to eat soup (more of a meat/potatoes kind of guy).  

For $6 total, I'll definitely be going back.  Next time, I may just stick to a full order of udon and call it a day though.
author: Banana S.

description:
Affordable japanese which is never really cheap especially given the address.  You can get comfortably fed here for less than $5bucks.
