I like the udon noodles and wish I had some now as i'm battling a cold.  Love the toppings and spice kick as they make this small space work.  Sushi is prepackaged and just ok, definitely better than the gummy taste of safeway or traders but that seaweed salad is the bees knees 

I also enjoy the walk thru Jackson Sq to get here as its the only area in SF that reminds me of Beacon Hill
author: Clark G.

description: Cash only!!!!! Super fast service but the chicken looked like it was boiled. Sushi was ok.
author: B M.

description:
nothing really new to add here.

super affordable prices, tasty food, friendly people, and they open early.

someone told me recently that this place has been in the same location for around 30 years or so - it's very easy to see why.
author: Mark A.

description: Fast, cheap and clean. A little salty to me. Within the walkable location from FiDi. Cash only so no cash no lunch. Will come back again.
author: Daisy M.

description: From out of town, had a craving for noodles and this establishment popped up as a nearby suggestion. Delicious, fresh and a good price for lunch. I knew that I made a good choice when I saw a line out the door when I turned the corner.
author: Christine G.

description: I don't understand why people give this place good reviews. I think it might be because it's because this area is a lunch dead zone so they grade on a curve. There are very few places to get a decent sandwich or takeout in this odd little corner of the Financial District. It's equally difficult to walk to North Beach, Chinatown, or below Market Street, so you're kind of stuck with a dozen sub-par choices unless you want to go for a 20-minute round-trip walk or shell out for a $12 fancy salad. I tried the chicken teriyaki, which appeared to be reheated poached chicken with an overly sweet, runny sauce that permeated overcooked rice. A sad orange slice and limp iceberg lettuce with Thousand Island dressing. The soba noodle was better, but not by much. Felt kind of gross and disappointed afterward. Like bad sex.
author: Casey C.

description:
Cons:
-not the best quality, but for $5 or less, you can't complain
-portions aren't that filling, but for $5 or less, you can't complain

Pros:
-friendliest people ever, they're very endearing
-really quick service, I'm usually in and out within a minute
-pretty cheap, I can get a satisfactory meal for about $4.25
-you get to add your own spicy sauce to the udon, somehow that makes me feel empowered

I like coming here when I need to grab a quick lunch and not necessarily for quality. If you're looking for a fancy-schmancy sushi buffet that costs $50 then look somewhere else, but this place is good enough for lunch.
author: Justin K.

description:
This place was a life saver when I had my internship in San Francisco last Winter!

As you might imagine, living in a student budget is super hard, and San Francisco is one of those places that you can be grateful that no one gave you a ticket for breathing too much! 

Yo Yo's is literally a whole in the whole, it is just a kitchen, no seating areas, in which you go in, order, and leave. They have a small menu, which makes them fast and great at what they do. 

I woould always order my favorite, soba noodles with eveything in it. The food was always warm, tasty, and cheap! I think it's healthy too, I mean, it's buckwheat noodles, fish ball, seaweed, and spices! :] 

For the price you're paying, less than $5 IN SAN FRANCISCO (yes, in San Francisco!), this place kicks ass by delivering food that fills you up and keeps you warm and cozy in a cold winter day at work. 

This is like fast food, but it all around beats Mc'Donalds. 

Keep it up Yo Yo's!
You'll always have people going back to you... like a yo yo... 
omg... i'm such a cornball!!! HAHAHA
author: Anna S.

description: The good man Joseph said one soup is tasty, this other one is healthier. Got the healthy one and it tastes delicious. Just found a new soup locale.
author: Javie M.

description:
Still reeling from my half order of soba. It was SO good. It was also 3 puny dollars. WHAT EVEN.

Working in FiDi means scrounging for reasonably-priced food, and thanks to the reviews here, I found Yoyo's. Feeling a little unsure of myself after looking at the In-n-Out-sized menu, I watched the regular in front of me order himself a full bowl of hot soba. I decided to follow his lead, and am so glad I did. 

The soba noodles themselves are amazing. I'm not sure if they make them in-house, but they sure taste like it. The broth has a great miso flavor with a nice onion-y bite--definitely one of the best I've ever had. The seaweed is--well, seaweed, but it goes great with everything else in there (tempura flakes, bean curd). I had never had tempura flakes before and loved them! Also, the mom and pop owners are really sweet. He politely asked if I wanted to put chili in my soup before closing the lid (which I recommend, even if you're not into spicy stuff).

You can also order the soups hot or cold, depending on the weather. Even though it was a beautiful 70+ degree day, the idea of cold soup just didn't appeal to me. Maybe next time? I might try the sushi, too. Unagi roll for $2.75? YES PLZ.

P.S. Cash only!
author: Rachel F.

description:
Half and half.

Sushi. Udon. Chicken teriyaki.

Tough choice. If only you could get small portions and try everything. Fortunately you can. 

Smoked salmon roll was great and the whole wheat noodles were perfect for a cold day. Chicken teriyaki was the only letdown. More sauce, less dark meat.

For about $11 it was enough for two lunches and more than enough culinary diversity.

Husband and wife couple couldn't have been more endearing, full of smiles and remembering the name of almost every customer in the door.

Portion were small, everything else left a large positive memory.
author: Jason B.

description: Quick food. Taste okay and a little bit too salty for me
author: Gary D.

description: It was a really yummy place! I just got some of the premade rolls and seaweed salad. When I saw the rolls were premade and sat on the counter I was worried at first but it all tasted fresh and cold. The woman at the counter was very kind!
author: Linzy B.

description:
I work only a few streets down from this wonderful little hole-in-the-wall place, and I come here whenever I want some super cheap and super satisfying Japanese grub. They've got udon, soba, seaweed salad, sushi, chicken teriyaki, gyoza and more, and it's ALL tasty. It's not a 5 star restaurant, but it's not pretending to be. 

My personal faves are the full-size udon (a little under $5!) and the half-order of chicken teryaki, which comes in a large to-go container with rice, a little bit of salad and orange slices (a little under $4). Hard to beat in the Financial District, where stupidly expensive food prices are the norm. 

On cold, blustery, miserable SF days, expect a line going out the door and around the corner -- they're THAT popular! But don't let that line worry you -- the 2 people working behind the counter are so efficient at taking orders and getting them out to you. 

The only con I can think of about this place is that it's cash only, but it's a small price to pay for...well, small prices! And if you work in the area but haven't gone to Yo Yo's, why haven't you gone yet??
author: Christine V.

description:
On one of the day working at a client's office, my coworker and I walked here from their office. Ordered a half udon and some CA rolls - about $6. Really good deal for FiDi.

The owners were hilarious. It was the day of the big Mega Million Drawings and seemed to be making fun of some regulars. It's great! I love that. 

Definitely will drop by and try it again, when I have more time for work.
author: Nina Y.

description: Great fast, healthy Japanese food. The udon  soup isn't vegetarian, unfortunately, but the make a great veg rice plate.
author: Shalom O.

description:
(See pic)

Cold and a bit dry weather, best to have simple good hot noodle soup.

Came here to pick up some delicious soba. Tons of great buckwheat noodles, delicious small pieces of tofu, seaweed and other Japanese flour style compliments. And it's only $5.25! They also have a gigantic jar of chili powder in case you want some. I added some and it really brought out the flavour.

Service was really nice and they also have some snacks and sushi.
author: T L.

description:
The noodles are top notch! Cheap, delicious, and fresh. Friendly owners with clean little shop. Will make this a regular lunch spot.

For vegans complaining about labels: Go back to Planet All-About-You

Sheesh
author: James W.

description:
Don't fret don't cry
the line is long but it's worth a try.

The Japanese couple has been working the snack bar for years, and they're super fast and helpful.  Oh, and it helps that the food is delicious and cheap.

The line moves through at a rate of 1 person per 20 seconds.  Beat that, Chipotle!
author: Eugene L.

description: I love this place - mostly because of the cute couple that works there!  They definitely make their food with love. The Soba noodle soup is the best! Not as big of fan of the teriyaki, but they are so nice and cheap they deserve 5 stars.
author: Autumn S.

description: My mom used to bring me home soba and sushi from them all the time and it was always a treat every time she brought it home and this was 10 years ago. This place has quick consistent quality of food and service. It's also great to get the soba to go and eat at a laster date as long as you ask for the noodles and soup separate. It gets five stars not because it's amazing fine dining food, but if you want a great, quick, go to lunch this is the place to get it. This place has been open for so long and that itself tells you how good this place is and how it continues to survive!
author: Kathy B.

description:
Came here with my friend the other day  - she knew of it and we were hungry.  It was nearly 2 in the afternoon...we were hungry.

Came here not knowing what to expect. Its a really tiny little shop between Chinatown and FiDi. I saw the corner Starbucks before I saw this place. Down side - there's no chairs or anything to eat at the place. Or outside. You have to walk a while...

Even though I didn't see it at first, it was worth it to come! At 2PM, no one is there, and the couple working are super sweet.  The elderly man took our order, and the nice lady in the back made it - she even called out "I hope you enjoy your meal!" to us as we left. Nice.

We split an order of Soba and it was DELICIOUS!  Soba noodles, with tons of extra stuff. I don't even know what it was, but it was SOO GOOD! There's these puffy rice things on top, next layer was seaweed, then some stuff that looked like the Chinese deep fried tofu puffs, a tofu and one of those little white sliced things with a pink swirl in it. I have no idea what they are, but they are delicious, and I shall consume it all.  Oh, yeah, And the soba on the bottom. HA.  They also wait to put on the lid so you can cram as much chili powder as you want on the top. Good stuff!

I like how they give you an option to do half and full orders, just because some people don't have a huge appetite.  Its cheap. Its fast. And the service is friendly! I am a fan!
author: Lily W.

description:
It honestly doesn't get any better than this in terms of eating lunch in the Financial District area. The food is delicious, inexpensive, high quality, and quick. There's literally nothing more that you can ask for.

I get cold soba with wasabi and a side of 6 piece california roll (not normally a fan of california rolls but these are great)
author: Jesse F.

description:
Someone I know said that he comes here for lunch at least 3x a week.  By that, you know that it is comforting enough to eat often and there must be something special about it.  What I found out that yes, the noodles are easy to eat but also that it is CHEAP.  I got a half order of udon for $2.25 and a seaweed salad for $1.65.  AND not to mention, it DID fill me up.  If that's not a deal then I don't know what you're smoking.

Udon is usually very plain in my eyes (at least in the states where there is little variation).  It's just simple, salty broth with really fat noodles.  But here they're not as fat which I actually like because they're not as slippery or filled with water.  They top it with kamaboko (that pink and white fish cake), aburaage (tofu pockets), seaweed (big slices), and little puffy things.  Before putting the lid on it, they'll ask you if you want some spice which you can sprinkle to your desire.  Unfortunately what I did notice was that the udon broth was a little too salty to drink by itself.

The seaweed salad left something to be desired because although it was good, it needs to be eaten with something (udon in this case) or if standing alone, it needs some raw fish or even squid to accompany it.  I saw that they also sell different varieties of rolls to-go which I love!  I can't believe how inexpensive the food is here and how the portions are small enough where you can get a couple things to throw some excitement into your lunch meal.
author: Shannon L.

description:
What defines a hole in the wall? This place does.

Cheap. Fast. Mom and Pop.

It's not by any means gourmet.  But this place is serious.  About 7 options on the menu. Cash Only. In and out for under $6.

- Chicken Teriyaki: Half order is a good size with a salad and an orange sliver.  It's basic generic teriyaki sauce over a baked chicken breast. 
- Udon: Nice and warm, with a littl ebit a tempura and tofu kicked in.
- Sushi rolls: Cafeteria quality sushi, but it hits the spot for a quick fix.

This place has become a staple, because it's quick and easy.  The married couple serving it up, with the wifey hustling in the back preparing the orders and the hubby taking in the cash.  It's a great thing. 

But tip: Go early, because line can get long.  If you are in the line, line along the west part of the sidewalk, and move to the side. Don't block the sidewalk
author: Natalie G.

description:
For what it is, I say 5 stars.  Haven't been here in a few years, but happened to be in that part of the city and popped in for some Udon.  

Prices are perfect and food is absolutely consistent.  I have had better Udon, but this place is always just right and I am happy when I leave.

Why can't I ever find any Vegan or Vegetarian options in the North Bay as easily?
author: Larry W.

description:
I'm mid-way through my first order from here ever and I joined Yelp to review this place. WOW!

There was a line out the door (waited less than 10 minutes) and one of the smallest menu's I've ever seen: udon, soba, edamame, potstickers, 3 kinds of sushi rolls, and that's pretty much it. I got a half order of the udon, which I was skeptical about because I'd never had it, but it seemed like what everyone was getting. No wonder! It's hot and delicious! I even like the bean curd in it, and I usually hate bean curd! I also got six assorted pieces of sushi: fresh, simple, yummy but nothing fancy. For this fantastic and filling lunch, I paid a whopping $5.35.

Service was highly efficient but friendly. They have this place running like a machine.

If you work in the area, I highly recommend stopping by and eating your lunch at one of the many parks in the area. I will be going back regularly.
author: Rachel W.

description: Good-value udon to go.  Though I was charged $5.75 instead of the $5.25 noted on the board. Did the price just go up? Still a great steal! Long line indeed but moves fast.
author: Formo S.

description:
Not a sit-in, just "take it and go" :)

- Simple menu. 
- Both soba and udon were yum. They serve both noodles hot and cold.
- Great price!
- Long, but fast lines at lunch time.
- Wish there was a place to sit...and/or park since I had to drive to get here =/
author: Frannie C.

description:
Half sized container of soba (or udon) for only $3.00?? I'm there!

Tasty--veggies, fishcake, tofu, and yummy, yummy hot broth.  (Also there is fried tempura on top, which I thought was gross, because well I don't like things that were once crisp to get soggy in my food, i.e. soggy cookies previously dipped in milk kind of thing.) *slurp slurp*

12 pieces of sushi (mixed variety) for under $6.00? Count me in... savory goodness! It was not hot, nor was it ice-cold.  Quality was great! 

Yeah, my lunch was around $8 but it was oh so so good! :D 

Total hole-in-a-wall place.  Owners = friendly, efficient and nice!  
(They have other fun Japanese snack items too!)

Pay with cash! You won't regret spending a single red cent!   (Great find in the FiDi!)
author: Fannie S.

description: Hola yo soy mexicano y vengo a San Francisco cada viernes y siempre me ordeno 1/2 ORDEN de chiken  teriyaki esta muy delicioso se los recomiendo 100% y aparte esta barato  menos de $6.00
author: Gustavo R.

description:
Small little hole in the wall, literally. No place to sit down, just a pick up and go kinda place. 

Ordered the udon. The broth was flavorful. I didn't care for the tempura pieces tossed into the soup so I think I'll go without next time. 

Quick and easy lunch, not to mention cheap!!!
author: Jeannie L.

description:
if you come in right before they are closing you can get what they have left with great discount.
tried the veggie dumpling and sushi with tofu skin(?)
decent.
If I pass by again I will for sure buy here again.
author: Rina C.

description: I don't work anywhere near this hole in the wall but I love them. Their food is far from orgasmic but it is what it is... cheap and fresh food to go. I typically get the half order of chicken teriyaki, very basic broiled thigh meat with sauce, a small side of salad with thousand island style dressing and an piece of orange. Their udon is also tasty although I recommend ditching the termpura pieces that comes with it. Soba is also in the same league as their udon. For an average eater, you'll be satisfied with spending $5 or less here.
author: Andrew L.

description: If you're eating on the cheap, this is the place to go. I think a full bowl of udon with loads of tenkatsu, seaweed, some fishcake, and tofu is about $6 dollars after tax. Pretty darn good for the financial district. And it all tastes really good especially the flavorful broth. The noodles were a little foreign texturally-wise, but it was still good. There's only one table inside with two seats, so keep that in mind.
author: Andrew S.

description: Let's just say, you get what you pay for. $2.50 for a half order of udon, and the serving size is perfect if you have a small appetite like me. The udon came topped with tempura bits, fishcake, seaweed, and some tofu, and you have the option of adding chili flakes, which i accidentally went a bit overboard with... but i kind of liked the kick it added to the broth. The noodles were a bit overcooked in my opinion, but overall the udon was quite good for what I paid. The people working there were also really friendly and fast with their orders. The large udon (huge!) is $4.50 I believe, so if you're looking for a filling, dirt cheap meal, this is the place to go!
author: Angela K.

description:
I love this place. Good food. Cheap. Friendly owners!

I always get the half-order of udon ($2.50) or half-order of hot soba noodles ($3.00). It's the perfect portion for lunch. I always get it with everything: seaweed, tofu, and tempura flakes. I also add on chili powder before he closes the lid. It is definitely worth it and very affordable, especially in the Financial District.

It gets really busy during peak lunch hours, around noon and they close at 3pm.
author: Aiza B.

description:
Anytime that you can find lunch for under 10 dollars in SF, is an automatic 1 star.  And when the food is above average?  Another star.  

They're a mom and pop shop, with the mom working the noodles and the pop running the cashier.  Their Udon noodle ($5 bucks) is very hearty and a great change to the sandwiches around the areas.  You can get fresh tofu, or soba noodles for alternatives.  

Chicen teriyaki is ok...I would go for the udon.  

Only one table in the store, expect to take it to go.  There can be a line during rush hour (12:15-1pm).  And  I believe it is cash only.
author: Kevin T.

description: The price is really really cheap. I usually go there after school for the soup($3.5 only). The food honestly taste average, and the sushi are not made by sushi rice I guess. I think I can make those at home myself too, but I can't complain because I got 6 pieces sushi for $1!! No seating spaces but the owners are extremely nice. You can go to the Starbucks next to it if you really want a place to sit down.
author: Christina S.

description:
Probably the quickest sushi purchase I have ever made. I was in and out of the place in less than a minute. The crab'n'avocado makis were delicious and fresh. For $5.5, they were great value too.

I'll definitely come back for lunch.
author: Johann R.

description:
Found my new favorite lunch place in SF!! The food is delicious and super affordable. 

They serve sushi, udon, soba, and various side dishes like edamame, seaweed salad, and gyoza. You can get a full size or half size of the noodles which is great because I love to mix and match. I've been getting the half order of udon with everything (the toppings include fried tofu, tempura batter, and seaweed) and a 6 piece sushi. There are a few kinds of sushi such as California rolls, unagi and cucumber roll, smoked salmon roll, avocado roll, and takuan roll (pickled daikon). I really like the California roll and smoked salmon roll. The half order of noodles and the 6 piece of sushi is very filling for me, and I can get all that food for less than $6!! 

The couple who owns this place works so quickly. The husband takes the orders and the wife packs the noodles. This place is definitely the definition of mom and pop shop. 

Although it is a bit of a walk from my office in the financial district, the walk is totally worth it!!
author: Ayaka S.

description:
Super quick and friendly service, consistent meals, and CHEAP as heck! 

It honestly doesn't get any better than this for locals looking for a quick and cheap work lunch to take back to the office (yes, I said back to the office because there is absolutely NO seating here. That is unless you care to sit by yourself in the corner). 

What to order:
-Their teriyaki chicken over brown rice is pretty tasty! Their half order portions are very filling so you can honestly feed yourself (and maybe even a tiny friend) for under $4.50! 
-Their udon noodles taste a little generic and aren't filled with the most substantial items, but hell, you are getting it for less than 5 bucks. What the heck are you complaining about? Eat it! 
-Any of their pre packaged sushi. It's not Morimotto's by any means, but it'll do :) 

Yay! I am a fan. I promise you'll be one too. Give this place a visit!
author: Jasmin W.

description:
This is one of my favorite stops for a cheap, good lunch in the Financial District. Sure, it's got no seating, but service is friendly and fast and the udon is really good. I usually order Udon with all the fixins, and perhaps some seaweed salad.

Most of the other items are solid, but not as impressive. Still, for less than five dollars and a one minute turnaround once you work your way through any line, it's hard to argue against for a lunchtime craving. I've dragged co-workers here more than once.
author: Tea P.

description:
Short, simple list of lunchtime items, all freshly made, served by the nicest people.     When I worked downtown, I got lunch at Yo Yo's probably two days a week.  Just went back, and they had added a few new items, but everything was perfect as usual.

Normally, one reserves 5 stars for something really out of the ordinary.  The food here is not innovative or unusual, and it's not a sit-down place, but for what it is, it is as good as it gets, which is the definition of 5 stars on Yelp!
author: charles h.

description:
I tried the Udon Noddle Soup and an order of the Teriyaki Chicken.The
price is cheap but the food is not out of this world.I also do not like the
skin left on the chicken.The people are friendly and pretty quick to get
your order together.
author: Buddha B.

description: Cheap yummy sushi not comparable to Safeway or TJ's. Really really fresh!!!
author: Neha A.

description:
Go ahead and treat yourself to a full order of udon, its only $4.50. I made the mistake of grabbing the half order for $2.50, thinking I was getting a steal of a deal on lunch. But my appetite begged to differ with me. 

I got the udon with everything and sprinkled some chili powder on it. My friend and I went to the park to sit and eat, a nice, crisp lunch in the city. The udon was really good and I really liked the little tempura and tofu they added in. Its fresh and not too salty, but still flavorful.

Safe to say I am definitely going back and definitely going to get a full order for their udon soup. $4.50 is an amazingly small amount to spend on lunch when you're in the financial.
author: Analisa S.

description: I've been eating at Yo Yo's since 1999. The soba and tofu bento box is always good, and I love supporting a local family. Joseph and Lidia are great!
author: Yum N.

description:
This little place is perfect for lunch when you work in the area!  They have a variety of perfectly portioned and delicious sushi, udon, and chicken teriyaki meals - that will never cost more than $10.  I always feel like I'm getting a lot of items then the owner rings me up and it's so cheap!  

One tip: CASH ONLY!
author: Heather B.

description:
Started a new job in this neighborhood 3 weeks ago and have been trying new places.  I happen to walk by this place while I was running an errand and made a mental note to check it out.  Glad I did because it's definitely a new go-to place for me.

I had the full size udon with all the fixens and sushi rolls.  Really good and check, hit the spot.  Will definitely try the half order of cihcken + half order of udon next time.
author: Christina W.

description:
Yo Yo's ... oh how I love thee, let me count the ways.

I've since stopped working in the city, but today, today, I really really craved Yo Yo's.  I'm feeling under the weather and all I could think about was some of that delicious broth, 1/2 order of udon with chicken, tempura, seaweed and extra tofu.  

I miss the owners - the lady who smiles a smile of recognition and gratitude that I'd frequent so often.  No seriously, you're the one doing ME a favor by feeding me delicious MSG goodness.  She always knew what I was in the mood for and mind you, my orders were tricky. 

I miss you Yo Yo's.  Alas, till our paths cross again.
author: Kathleen W.

description: The price is really unbeatable in Yo-Yo's, is like a traditional mom and pap's store where the store owner is very kind and friendly, they always greet you with a smile and a positive vibe. The udon taste pretty good, but kind of on the salty side, so if you like strong favor then the udon is recommended for you. I like everything about the store, except not too many options to pick from. But still, overall, good price and decent food.
author: Janice S.

description: What a sad state of affairs that this is one of the best rated Japanese restaurants downtown. The food is crap. First of all, they use way too much sugar. Second, there is nothing but carbs here. The Udon soup is noodles, with option to add more carbs in the form of tempura flakes, and the only real food that can be added is tofu or seaweed. Poured into a plastic container that melts and puts chemicals into the broth. The rest of the stuff is all carbs, carbs, carbs. Noodles or white rice or some other tofu-based crap. I got the only meat I could find - rolls with cheap smoked salmon and fake crab meat, and they are barely edible. I feel bloated and unsatisfied. It seems all the good reviews are so excited about how cheap it is. If cheap is the goal, then, yes, it's cheap. But, it's not real food.
author: Eater S.

description:
The food here is decent and beyond cheap. A regular lunch spot for me and my coworkers. Although having it every single day gets kind of tiring, you really can't beat the deal here. My favorite is udon w/ everything, but their soba is legit also. Chicken teriyaki is mehh... really just boiled chicken with sauce on top over some white rice--however, that's not what I come here for anyway.

The food, honestly, probably deserves only 4 stars. However, the couple that works here isthe nicest couple I've ever met which catapults them into 5 starts and beyond for me. Coming here to buy a nice hot meal from honest, hardworking people just makes the food that much more enjoyable.
author: Melody S.

description:
I made special plans to try this out because it was one of the four star places that popped up when I yelped for cheap lunch options in FIDi.

I read through a lot of reviews and was really looking forward to some basic yet tasty udon (1/2 order $3) and wakame salad ($1.75)

Based on speed and price I'd give this place 5 stars.
Based on quality I'd give it...2 maybe 3. 

The wife/husband team was super fast, got in a line (4-5 people ahead of us) and ordered, paid, got food, sat down AND finished eating in 15 minutes. I'm a super slow eater too. There is only one small table in the corner with 2 stools. Luckily, no one else was expecting to sit down and eat at a place like this, so we got it!

Food

Udon - I cannot believe I did not see a flood of comments about how this isn't really udon. The noodle is not udon noodles, it isn't even the knife cut or the hand pulled with the slight al dente, qq thing going on. It was just some thick noodle that didn't have any of the chewiness I like in a noodle. It came out fast, the soup was good enough, I just wish it had real udon noodle. I'd take that quick frozen boiled udon I get at grocery store. I would not get this again. Confused...call it noodle soup not udon.

Smoke salmon sushi - gummy, rice over vinegared and the salmon never full made it through the sushi rice slices, it was weird... the fish would only go half way through each rice sushi slices. ($2.75). Not worth getting.

Wakame salad - standard. 

So if you're looking to support a small business with good service and eat something cheap, fast and hot go for it. I probably won't be back, but there was a continuous line during my 15 minutes in the store. Efficient service. Imagine if the food was better...this place would be even busier. I did hear a lot of people ordering chicken teriyaki on brown rice, so maybe that one is decent.
author: Karin L.

description:
adorable couple serving tasty japanese food to the hungry people of.. san francisco.

love this place.  the couple who own the place are very friendly and accommodating.  CHEAP. Varied portions (you can choose). 

I picked up 1 inari, seaweed salad, 6 piece california/unagi roll all for under $5.  There's usually a line around lunchtime, but it's worth the wait.  

PS. They sell hi-chew candy as well!
author: Melody T.

description:
Yo Yo Ho Ho, these noodles are for me! 
Are there more words I can remix to this pirate song?

This place is cheap, filling, and yum. All the necessary adjectives for me hand over my money without complaining.  The cute little couple makes everything with their own little hands. Well, this one time I saw the cute wifey making the California rolls, so I assume she makes everything else. I always get the soba or udon noodles which cost less than $5 for the full order or around $2.75 for the half order AND the California rolls, which are around $2.50 for 6 pieces. 

It's oh so good on those cold SF days, but just yum in general.  The only drawback is that there is no dine-in area except for one tiny table which you're probably not supposed to sit in anyway, but I will forgive them because it reminds me of a friendly little hut.  There's usually areas nearby - the plaza by the BofA where they have places to sit by a fountain!

Cash only.
author: Dolores L.

description:
I usually reserve terms like awesome, cheap, and friendly for my brothel reviews, but...  
And I still don't know if the husband is also Japanese, but that only adds to the mystique.
author: R F.

description: As many have said -- it's cheap -- but nothing here is that great.  It's all kind of OK, and I guess since SF is a seriously lacking town when it comes to good japanese, people are willing to give this place a pretty high average.  There's no seating, and the inside is pretty dingey.  If you are near the area it's worth a try, but it's definitely not as great as some people are purporting here :(
author: Yan L.

description:
Yo Yo's used to be one of my favorite spot for lunch when I was working in financial district in SF--it is a little far to walk for lunch break, but a nice day, good walk, and cheap but delicious food, definitely worth it! Why not?

It is a take-out only place, run by a very cute couple, a tiny little store, usually have a line, but they are very efficient, the wait is always shorter than the line looks.

Their chilli sauce is definitely the BEST! and it is surely one of the key reasons that I become so addicted to their food.

While writing this review, I really miss it! Next time if I go back to that area, I will definitely go there--get the noodles with lots of chilli pepper, then eat at the park nearby...one of my best memories of the old days...
author: Chloé N.

description:
I was wrong to give this place 4 stars only. This has now become my go-to lunch place. The food is great, the prices are extremely low, and the service is always quick and wonderful!

I usually get a half order of udon with everything (tempura flavor, seaweed, and bean curd), a container of seaweed salad, and a single piece of inari (tofu pouch with rice inside). All that costs a whopping $4.65!

Give this place a try, you'll love it!
author: John C.

description:
I heart Yo Yo's.
This is one of the best mom and pop places near FiDi.  The food is simple and inexpensive.  The owners are great.  If you are a regular, they will remember your name and order!

I usually go for the full order of udon and half teri chicken for lunch!  Everything comes out to about $7.  Great deal for the amount of food.  And it taste AWESOME!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  

The place is small.  So plan on taking your food back to the office.  Your co-workers will be drooling with envy.  

Hey, you smell that???  It's the smell of EPICNESS!!!!!
author: Norm K.

description:
I crave Yo Yo's!  Delicious, easy, kind, cheap - yes please!  Definitely my go-to place for lunch.  I wish the adorable couple that runs it could teach other lunch spots how to move a line as quickly and friendly as they do!  Always smiling!

Usually I'll get the veggie rolls and some seaweed salad but occasionally I'll treat myself to some Udon soup - half order!
author: Bonnie P.

description: You get what you pay for. I go here for the delicious Udon at a great price and speedy service. The line is usually out the door but they have a system and it works to get everyone in and out in 5 minutes or less.  Cash only.
author: Holly P.

description: What a powerhouse. This couple has figured out fast and good at the right price. No where to sit, but if you want a lot of food come for pickup and walk to Levi's plaza to eat. I got the half chic teriyaki on brown rice + half udon soup for $7 and it was enough for two.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I haven't written a "nice" review in a while.  But wow, this place deserves it.  These folks serve up a delicious cheap udon noodle soup. 

I just know you're going to come here and say, "shit look at this line, I'll just get a craptastic sandwich from Starbucks instead."  Don't do that, dummy.  The line moves, as they say, hella quick.
author: jack p.

description:
Alright, something has to be said for the best hidden deal around the Financial District....

4 bucks gets you a LARGE udon or soba with all the accoutrements and mouthgasmic flavor you could ask for. Such a great deal, and so comforting on those oh-so-deceiving san francisco summer days where it looks nice but is still 50 degrees and windy. 

The mom and pop that runs this place knows how to make a good meal. They whip it up quick, and you leave completely satisfied (almost guilty for not paying more...). Try the little side dishes too  that they sell--so yummm.

I heart Yo Yo's.
author: Samantha R.

description:
Cheap. Fast. Good.  For a to-go lunch spot that offers healthy Japanse options, it doesn't get much better than this.  I even questioned writing a review so as not to let  more people in on the awesomeness of this hole-in-the-wall spot, but the couple that runs the place is just so friendly and cute, I have to give credit!

I've had the udon soup and the sushi so far.  Nothing will blow your socks off but it's quality and tasty.  A half udon with everything and california roll (they don't use mayo!) cost me $5.45.  I really appreciate that you can do half or full orders because the half is enough food for me.  Next time, I'm going for the chicken teriyaki (brown rice available!) and seaweed salad.  Or maybe the pot stickers and soba noodles ... many options for a small shop.

Cash only.  Sometimes the line is long but this couple is efficent so it goes fast.  Just have your cash out and know what you want to order by the time you get to the counter or you'll annoy the regulars!
author: Caitlin T.

description: Ideal lunch place with one of the city's best seaweed salads. Very affordable, for 7 dollar you'll get sushi, seaweed salad and a bowl of excellent udon. I used to go to school near by so I've had uncountable many lunches here, and everytime I go back to San Francisco I'll make sure I'll drop by for a quick pick up lunch.
author: Linn L.

description: I don't even remember why I thought my first experience here was only 3 stars, but I've become a regular here in the last year and love their soba noodle soup.  Tasty broth, great noodles.  Wonderful service.
author: B. Y.

description:
2.8/5 not what i expected.

i think the soba was great. totally what i was craving. the other stuff i tried, eh. should have just skipped on those. also, when i was here, there was a lady who was speaking with the owners. at first i thought it was a consultant...then i realized i think it was a health inspector O_o
author: Alvin D.

description:
Really. I really, really, really love these folks. Half udon with everything, salmon maki, daifuki mochi (red!) and a bag of nori maki arare for later.

Mr. and Mrs. YoYo are beyond nice, the food is cheap and good, and it's fast fast fast.

I have been going here 2-3 times a week lately :)
author: Eugene A.

description:
The Yo! Oh, the memories I've had here. This was my first meal when I started working. This is the source of the infamous "double yo" (two Yo Yo meals consumed in one sitting). The question, "more spicy?," is forever engraved in my head. 

The couple behind the counter is one of the friendliest I've known. And they remember all our names and our "usual" orders. It's pretty crazy considering how many people go here.

For the price, which is cheap, the food is not bad at all. I usually go with the half order of teriyaki chicken and grab a box of california sushi rolls. Of course, this place is no gourmet Japanese food but for some reason, I still enjoy this place. 

If I ever start working in that part of the financial distract again, I'd be happy to come back to Yo Yo's. 

4 stars.
author: Jonathan L.

description: Great family owned business. Try the udon. You won't regret it. Comes out piping hot with all of the fixings. All for under $5. That's including the sushi rolls platters and terriyaki bento boxes. Awesome lunch spot for quick take out sushi.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: To be honest, I was really surprised at how much I enjoyed the sushi. Do NOT be detered by the line! They are crazy fast and efficient. The only reason I'm giving them 4 stars is because of their lack of variety. I've been to places with pre-rolled sushi before but their variety pack was VERY fresh tasting and quite scrumptious! And I got 6 CA and 6 salmon rolls for $5.50. WHAAAAAT?!
author: Charity W.

description:
Their noodle soup is truly amazing; when you're in the need for some noodle soup for lunch - this place is the place to go. Service is fast and efficient, food is good. The full order of chicken teriyaki can feed 2, and the noodles will fill your stomach up real good. The rolls are pretty average to good - but it's the hot food that steals the show.

The line is sometimes long, but it really does move quickly. Take away only.
author: Vicki L.

description:
I LOVE this place. It's near work and it's super cheap. I would rather buy lunch from here every day than bring my own lunch since it's SO CHEAP. 

Lunch today for example was less than $6.00. That includes a half order of chicken teriyaki with brown rice and two pieces of sushi. They have a variey of sushi available for vegetarians as well. They have prepackaged gyoza and edamame. They also sell udon and soba, full and half orders. Cash only. It's a small mom/pop joint, so it's really awesome to support their small business!

This is a great place to go if you want to just grab and go at lunch time.
author: Julie L.

description: This place is quick (lines move fast), inexpensive, and best of all, the service is wonderful.  I love supporting a small mom&pop store with such friendly owners who seem to enjoy what they do.  The food will probably not amaze you but it's decent and definitely worth the low prices you pay for it.  I personally like the vegetarian dumplings and sushi rolls and the best part is I can get full with just $5.
author: Lauren S.

description:
These are the nicest people in the world!!! Fast, tasty, cheap, fresh.

Love the soba, seaweed salad, plus some wasabi peas to go for afternoon snack.

How nice if more of life were filled with adorable hole in the walls run by good folks like Yo Yo's. Humane.
author: Stephen L.

description:
Can you find delicious food for a very good price, prepared in a clean facility by a very friendly staff? Can all these good attributes be found in the same place of business, in San Francisco?
Yes, they can.
Yoyos is simply the best hole-in-the-wall food place in the city.
Japanese-style food to go, always delivered fast and with a warm smile from either one of the owners-operators of this welcoming joint.
It makes me so happy to see good people succeed, and to know that some of the best things in life do not have to cost an arm and a leg.
Someone should make a business case out of Yoyos to teach new business owners how to deliver excellent goods and services at incredibly competitive prices.
author: Mauro M.

description: I love this place..unfortunately I no longer work in the city so I just long for the days of udon with everything and extra hot spice ontop.  I wish they were open weekends or delivered..:)
author: Gina W.

description: Their Chicken teriyaki and udon are one of my favorite lunch choice and they are all very reasonably priced. I would go there over any other places around financial district.
author: Jinwoo K.

description:
Decent place for a quick and cheap lunch. Half order of the chicken teriyaki. Comes with choice of white or brown rice, small salad and a slice of orange. Simple really.. Don't expect too much and you won't be disappointed. 

Plenty of other things too such as cali rolls, udon, etc. Will return when craving rice for lunch
author: Jason C.

description: I came here all the time for lunch when I worked in San Francisco. The food is delicious and cheap.  I never spent more than $5 on a meal here.  The line is usually out the door (because the shop is small) but it moves very quickly.  My go-to dish was always the half chicken teriyaki on rice.  Their California rolls were also very good.  There is no place to sit and eat here so you'll need to find somewhere to enjoy your meal. So glad this place is still around!
author: Janet E.

description: Very tasty udon at a reasonable price. Decent sushi. Unagi rolls run out really quickly though, so come early in the morning if you want any.
author: Eric C.

description:
Yo Yos is one of my favorite lunches when I want to pick something up and take it back to work. And the owners are such hard-workers who always smile and show their appreciate for your business. 

The first time I was here I actually forgot my wallet but they still gave me my food and told me to pay next time I was in. Such nice people!
author: Tony O.

description:
I wish I could give them 10 stars!  They are super fast, know my order and are always so friendly and happy.  I feel like I'm dropping in on my aunt and uncle and I'm Colombian/American - not Japanese!!  
The full udon is a great deal and super delicious.  ...and now that they added pot stickers you can't go wrong.  Everyone I bring there loves the food and the husband and wife team that run/own the place.  It's everything you want in a lunch spot if you like Japanese udon.

Be good to yourself and eat there!!!!!
author: J R.

description:
YoYo's....where do I start? Here is a numbered list. 

1. The proprietors of this place are so nice that it makes me want to cry. 

2. The nice man who works there seems sad when I do not get chili powder in my udon. I hate the chili powder, but I feel so bad because he is second in niceness only to his co-proprietor that sometimes I shake a bit in. 

3. This is one of the very, very few affordable places to eat anywhere near my office. It's so cheap! Especially for the Delicious food you get. I mean, it's a steal. It's not just cheap, it is tasty. Often it is one or another. In life, I mean. 

4. I think the udon is just so yummy. Also, I get a little package of rolls for about $.02. Okay, I think it might be $1.50 No joke.
author: Leata H.

description: I've been eating here for years.  Soba is awesome.  Try it cold with wasabi!  I always get a small one so I can stock up on the other goodies--the marinated octopus, seaweed salad and sushi are great companions to the soba for a super lunch.
author: Bob S.

description: Best lunchtime value in the City, period.  Fast, friendly, fresh!  Yo Yo's is one of my favorite spots to stop during my lunchtime walk in the FiDi.  Grab half-order Soba and a six-piece Sushi for $6.25 and then head to Levi Plaza, the Embarcadero, or Walton park.  On the rare days that it seems too hot for soup try the COLD soba a refreshing, savory treat.
author: J E.

description:
Great and inexpensive hole in the wall Udon and Sushi walk in. It's truly amazing how fast and efficient the husband and wife are who O&O the place. Dispite YoYo's is in the middle of the Financial Dist they know all their customers by name and what they order. 

I hadn't gone in about 6 months and went back and the same thing...name and order down. I'm curious to see what happens when I go back after being away for a year.
author: Brandon D.

description: Best Udon & Soba noodles to go for under $5 anyone could possibly ask for! Husband and wife team have been here every day - friendly - and very fast - since at least 2007 when I started coming here!
author: Aaron R.

description: Love Yo Yo's! Such a good deal and yummy too! They are the most efficient and adorable little couple you will ever meet. Super friendly and the food is delicious. Definitely try the udon and chicken teriyaki! I especially love their brown rice because it's sticky. It's a great place to grab lunch if you're working in FiDi!
author: Reina G.

description:
This is my ideal lunch place. The food is delicious, inexpensive, quickly prepared, with friendly service. I wish there was one in every neighborhood I work in.

My favorite is the udon soup with everything. The broth is savory and well-seasoned, with tofu skin, seaweed, udon noodles and puffy rice. It is filling and warms you on rainy days like today. Their sushi is simple and fresh, and their octopus salad is tasty.

Today I got an udon with everything and an octopus salad for $7! No way can you find a comparable deal anywhere in the Financial District.
author: Lilia M.

description: This place is good because its cheap, convenient and edible. I don't think a place deserves more than three stars unless you can say something great about the food itself. I'd go back on days when i just want to "get lunch over with."
author: Will T.

description:
Delicious cheap homecooked food. 

The couple that owns the shop are so wonderfully kind and sweet. T
The soba noodles and soup are amazing and if you come here often enough they even remember your order!

I used to come here all the time when I worked in the area and even though I'm rarely in that part of town these days, I'll still make the trek to Yo Yos if I'm anywhere near the neighborhood.
author: Amy K.

description:
I'm getting reallly addicted to this place! It's a two person operation and they are super fast and friendly.
I first tried the hot soba noodles, but then I found my order of choice! Half order of udon with everything and half order of COLD soba with everything. The dollop of wasabi on the cold soba is a must! I don't usually like my food cold, let alone eat cold noodles, but somehow the chewy noodles in the cold sweet-ish sauce is quite refreshing. And the tofu they put in there is sooo good. Lots of flavor.   Just a really great, simple place to pick up lunch.
author: Mina T.

description: I had the half order of chicken teriyaki and it made me turn into a pescatarian.  It was just so depressing.  The service is cold and I'm sure their other dishes are great and they're working at that pace for efficiency purposes, but I don't think I would go back.
author: k h.

description:
Um, you just need to GET here.

This place is soupa (pun intended) doopa CHEAP!  

And the couple who works here are so friggin' nice!  MUCH nicer than the pho-nazis at this joint: http://www.yelp.com/biz/my-canh-san-francisco#hrid:P53IJIdf-SRZ1VA1HZVr3Q/src:self

Love them, the soup, and the cheap!
author: Karen F.

description:
Good cheap udon and soba. Excellent quick service, and if you go there often enough, they pick up on your preferences. "Big udon, no fish cakes?"

And the couple who run the place are the sweetest people in the world. They are cash only, though. I've had times where I've forgotten my money, and they don't mind me paying it the next day. 

Whenever I'm hungry and need a quick, good, cheap meal, I walk to Yo Yo's. Highly Recommended.
author: Hamlet A.

description:
Yo-Yo's is a solid place for anyone working nearby in The Financial to stop in and get lunch at.

Careful when you go, as the line can get out the door long.  But even at their busiest though, they really crank people out of there!  It's a ell oiled machine I tell you!

Things I have ordered:  Full and half orders of Teriyaki Chicken.  Very good.  Large order comes with a large portion of chicken and a large side of rice.  As well as a small side salad a few orange slices.  All for about $5.99 - not bad, not bad.  I've also had their edamame - not the best I've had, as I have to reheat when I get back to my office and it gets a little dried out, but maybe I just don't know how to use a microwave, could be possible.  

You can't go wrong with the price of Yo-Yo's.  I always see people getting soup in here too, next time I'll have to try some.  Update to follow.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
Yo Yo's is a wonderful place to grab lunch in the financial district. It's a mom and pop japanese shop. All orders are made to-go, there is no seating area.

It's extremely cheap and really delicious. They only offer a few items on the menu (soba, udon nooodle soup, chicken teriyaki, gyoza, a few sushi selections, and a few other things). The couple who run the shop are friendly and process orders quickly, so the wait is not bad at all! 

You can order half portions for under $3 and full portions for about $5! 

Definitely give this place a try! :-)
author: Monica T.

description:
I know I'm echoing everyone here, but I too would like to praise Yo Yo's value, taste, speed, and service!

Bf and I met here for lunch and split the udon, dumplings, and chicken teriyaki.  Next time, we'd probably get two udons instead - it proved to be the highlight of the meal.

As mentioned by other Yelpers, take your snacklings over to nearby Sidney Walton park for the perfect mid-day break from the daily grind :)
author: Allison B.

description:
Review based on take out sushi!

I am aware that Yo Yo's is well liked for it's udon, but today I was on the lookout for some quick and easy sushi. Reviews here mentioned "better than supermarket sushi", so I figured it was worth a try - not expecting or looking for gourmet standard.

First concern was that the sushi was prepacked but not placed in a refrigerator unit. It was reasonably cool in that area but not cold enough. However, it did taste fresh, so fingers crossed it will be fine. Second issue was the range or choice. There really wasn't much in the way of options, and the rice to filling ratio was a little high.

Having got the gripes out of the way, this is ok sushi. Nothing particularly special but acceptable for a grab-and-go lunch. As long as my stomach remains happy this afternoon 3 stars is about right. The fish tasted fresh and the rice was good. They gave me (white Englishman) chopsticks and didn't ask if I wanted a fork. I like this.

I will probably come back if I want a light lunch and I'm in a hurry in the future. Maybe in July when it's colder I'll try the udon...
author: Rich N.

description:
RUN don't walk to this literal hole in the wall. I have walked by this place for months now going to the taco truck across the street wondering, "hmmmm, that place must be good".

Today I went and I will go back again and again and again...

I had the Chicken Terriyaki (full order $5.50). YUM YUM YUM and hot and tasty...

Run, don't walk because the woman who makes the food is amazing and her man-friend sorting out the counter is fast and efficient.

You'll love it.
author: Mark M.

description: Came here with a friend few weeks ago, service was great. The food was really good! and super Cheap! we bought udon and california roll for just $6! definitely coming back next time! (:
author: Anna Y.

description:
This place makes a work day better.  It's around the block from my office, and praises for that.

"Half size" of the udon noodle soup will run you $2.25, is so good, and there's plenty of it.  They'll throw in some really great tofo also. As other's have mentioned, you can grab some sushi or snacks for cheap too.

The soup is just so good.  The couple that own it are also so lovely!
author: Amy P.

description:
Great value, good food, quick and easy!  I stopped by today to pick up some hot soba noodles (with everything - tempura, tofu and seaweed), gyoza and seaweed salad.  I was actually quite impressed.  The soba was quite tasty though the noodles were a tad bit too soft for my liking but not that bad.  The gyoza was just okay but it was so cheap.  I also like the seaweed salad which was quite flavorful and refreshing.  With that said, I've been really thirsty after my meal so there must've been a lot of salt (or MSG - hopefully not), otherwise I'm just extremely dehydrated today!

We ordered two hot soba noodles with everything, one gyoza, one seaweed salad and one drink for $14!  Can't beat that!  But there isn't anywhere to sit so make sure you plan accordingly.
author: Jessica T.

description: Cheap, simple, delicious udon. I'd also buy a side of gyoza and soak them in the soup. :)
author: C J.

description:
Oh how I love this place.  

Not only is it cheap, quick and easy, but the food is delicious and the soup and noodles come out piping hot.  I recommend the soba noodles, and I get the California rolls with my meal as well.

It's definitely not the type of place you bring someone out on a date to, or the type of place to relax and enjoy the decor.  There are no tables to sit, and their goal is to fulfill your order as quick as possible.

It's the type of place you go to when you need food and you need it quick.  The owners are happy to hurry on your order, and even to remind you if you've forgotten to add the chili powder to your noodles.
author: Erica D.

description:
I came here for lunch today after starting my internship for the summer in the FiDi. I looked for something close by that was "one dollar sign" cheap and soon got this place. Boy, am I happy that Yelp and Yo Yo's exists!

I went at around 12:15 pm and expecting the worst line ever, I was pleasantly surprised. There was a line out the door but that had more to do with the place being quite small rather than a lot of people being in line. While there were a handful in front of me, they are really efficient and work really well to get you out in a reasonable time. I was definitely surprised by how fast it was. The udon is fantastic and was definitely satisfying, perhaps I'll get the half next time as it got me pretty full. 

I think I will try the chicken tomorrow... The only bad thing about this place is that they do not accept credit cards. I never have any cash with  me! Also, I like my udon noodles thicker but hey, it was cheap, fast, and filing so it was still pretty damn good.
author: Rick C.

description:
There is no such thing as a free lunch but there are some great close-to-free lunch spots that are dam good too. This is one of those places.

Hello $4.00 for a huge portion of delicious udon soup? Um yes please, I'll be back.
author: Jill W.

description: Cool, fast, friendly place for noodles, sushi, chicken teriayki. Their food is not bad, but not great either. The soup isn't as salty as I remember, but their noodles got thinner. Not a bad place especially for the price. Love the husband & wife team!
author: Linda C.

description: I got sick later that night after having the California roll and was out of it for a week. Just because its cheap doesn't mean that you wont pay in other ways.
author: Sean P.

description:
Yo!

If you want authentic, affordable, and appetizing Japanese food, Yo Yo's is the place to grab a quick meal.

You can get the soba hot or old, udon, and California rolls (in big or small orders) and be out the door in a matter of minutes.

I've had the cold soba with the California rolls for about $5. Today I got seaweed salad and California rolls for $4 even. What a steal! Meet up with some friends to grab some fast, fresh food and walk over to a comfy spot to eat, as there is no seating in Yo Yo's.

Be aware, this place is cash only.
author: Valerie L.

description:
High quality and the cheapest place to eat downtown.
Half orders are enough for most items. You can get lunch for $3-4!
author: candice c.

description:
I come here all the time.  It's my favorite place to go to for sushi.  The place isn't fancy (in fact, quite small) but the prices are extremely reasonable.  It is a pick up and go place, no place to sit down and eat.

The owners are very friendly and very efficient.  The lines move fast even during the lunch hour rush.  I usually get the half udon and the 9-piece California rolls.  All for under $7!  Can't beat the price, especially in Financial District.
author: S L.

description:
Had high expectation for this place due to the solid 4 Stars, but this is just A-OK for me.

Got the half order of Udon with everything and California roll, for $5.20, pretty good deal.

Udon texture is pretty good, I like it.  The broth is super salty, I had to add some hot water in mine, but that did the trick.  Good amount of seaweed, fried tofu, one piece of fish cake.  Pretty good value for the price.

CA roll tasted pretty good, ordinary, again shouldn't have high expectation.

Overall, it was just ordinary.  $5.20 I'm full.  I'm just not impressed.

For similar type of restaurant, I would go for Sushi Bay instead.  And yes, they don't have half order udon, but they have half order bento :)
author: Gigi T.

description:
One of my coworkers is a regular at Yo Yo's -- I've often seen her at her desk with a tall plastic container filled with steaming udon noodles, and I have to admit that I was a tad jealous. I figured that I would rally the forces and get a small crew of people together to make the quick trek a couple blocks from the office to check it out.  There was a slightly intimidating line out of the door, but it moved briskly. Before I knew it, I was standing at the front counter..torn with indecision (even with the fairly simple menu). 

I ended up ordering the large portion of cold soba noodles in a light broth.  It was served with a slice of fish cake, some bean curd and cute lil' fried tempura batter balls, with a healthy dose of wasabi to kick up the intensity.  Oh, and I couldn't help but get the seaweed salad too, because it was insanely cheap!  And it was honestly, as good as what I've gotten at sit-down restaurants for 5 times the price!

Altogether, I only spent $6.60, and I had enough food for 2 meals...granted I wasn't particularly hungry today for some odd reason.

Yes, I'm going to be starting on my new Yo Yo diet! :)
author: Evelyn K.

description:
These people are EFFICIENT. Like they have it down to the TEE. Always a line, but never a wait. Asian people, I swear....

AND it's CHEAP. I mean, TACO BELL cheap. $5.

I wouldn't recommend the sushi. The soba noodles on the other hand.... It comes in two sizes: I'm hungry or I'm starving, in which I always choose the latter, duh. And I sprinkle lots of that chili powder too. Really hits the spot on a cold day in SF a.k.a. every day, because FML no one ever told me that SF was this consistenly chilly.
author: Sylvia L.

description: Small mom and pop place that has great fresh japanese food. THey also have option to take half order that I really like. Its a great place for a light lunch and good way to control your portion, just order half. I got chicken tereyaki and udon soup. Both tasted great - good healthy and delicious tasting lunch option. Prices are now higher..guess economy affects them too.
author: Try E.

description:
Where else can I get a cucumber roll for $1.85?  Cheap lunch that leaves you satisfied.  Sure, the salmon roll is smoked salmon and I've had better chicken teriyaki - but not at this price point!

Don't forget to add a little bit of spice to your udon/soba - I'm not a huge spice person but it's a really nice little dash of extra flavor.
author: Audrey C.

description:
Cheap and very tasty! Not too fancy, with limited options but am definately a fan!  Owned by a lovely couple with super fast service means its great for lunch.

Would agree with other reviews to say its not the best Japanese food - but their Udon soup is made right in front of you, and their sushi is pretty tasty.

Defintately would recommend - and will be back there again soo!
author: Beekay M.

description: The epitome of a "mom and pop shop," this place is run by the sweetest couple. The udon is cheap and hits the spot. A large udon ($4.50) is a huge portion, and you can add whatever toppings you want: bean curd, fresh chunks of tofu, seaweed, and tempura flakes. I recommend adding all, plus chili powder, to give the broth some flavor. The vegetable sushi is super fresh. The vegetable gyoza are bland and are stuffed with edamame; better to go with the fresh edamame in pods. Definitely worth a stop if you're in the area, looking for a quick and cheap take-out lunch.
author: Emma R.

description: This is my go-to Ma and Pa spot for good, cheap Soba or Udon. Literally one of the only places in the Fidi where you can cop a full lunch for under $6! I generally go for the Soba and Veggi pot stickers. The sushi rolls are pretty standard, not too fancy.  The couple that runs the place are quick, efficient and nice. The line is generally wrapped outside during peak lunch time, but don't let that deter you, it moves fast.
author: Krystal C.

description:
Bumped up one start for service. The couple there are very nice, and quick to serve you.

Great place for quick, cheap, good lunch.

Note- cash only
author: Eddy N.

description: This place is my go-to when I have a sushi or udon craving, and need something quick and good. The half order of udon is perfect when pairing it with a california roll. It's cash only but it's a small price to pay. And the two people working there are so fast. Don't be intimidated if there is a line out the door!
author: Kim O.

description: One of the few cheap eats in downtown for lunch! $5 gets you udon soup with all the fixins. Too bad it's not closer to work.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Recipe for looking economically indisposable to five hungry execs:

4 California Rolls
4 Smoked Salmon rolls
5 Seaweed Salads
3 Edamame packs

1. Take sushi rolls out of individual packs and arrange on a clean, shiny platter. Arrange the supplied ginger and wasabi chunks in a puffy green and peach pattern.
2. Place edamame from all packs in a nice bowl, with an extra empty bowl next to it for shells. 
3. Put seaweed salad into a bowl and mix with fork for that "freshly-tossed" look and add a fork for easy scooping.
4. Serve with a fresh pot of green tea to complete the gesture. 
___________________
Total: $29.95

Outcome: Impressed compliments, possible raises (though not likely), job security for at least another week.

And then for feeding yourself:

1 veggie roll
1 edamame pack

1. Eat straight out of the plastic container, because you don't have to impress yourself.
--------------------------
Total: $3

Economical success!
author: Kat E.

description:
I've been coming here for a long time and the couple that runs the place are super awesome! They know me by name and know what I'll order right when I walk through the door! Always friendly and happy! You cannot ask for a better service! 

The food is so yummy! It's super cheap for those that are on a budget and you do get what you pay for..so don't expect too much! The portion is huge and you can get a full meal with drink under $5!

I most definitely recommend it anyone who's in a rush and want something tasty and quick!
author: braydon a.

description: Yo yo's is perfect for a fast, cheap and tasty lunch.  Love the udon or soba noodle soup.  I order it with all the trimmings.  The chicken teriyaki leaves a bit to be desired, but the edamame, seaweed salad and veggie sushi are a nice addition to lunch.  The owners are friendly and very efficient.  And lunch for under $5 - who's complaining!?
author: Mac M.

description:
This is not delicious food. WHO CARES? It's serviceable, it's fast and holy crap is it cheap.

9-piece California roll
large whole orange
Diet Dr. Pepper
------------------------------
$5

Can't beat it.
author: Brittney G.

description: Over six months since my last visit (I now work in Mill Valley), the adorable husband and wife couple still remembered me and my order. Wow! The udon and seaweed salad were as delicious as ever and made me wish that I still worked close to Yo Yo's!
author: Meghan P.

description: This place is AWESOME, the Udon is always fresh and delicious. The cost is very low especially for the financial disctrict. If you are in the area you have to drop in. FYI it's not a sit down resturant.
author: R I.

description:
I love yo yo's. The cheapest lunch place in FiDi, but unfortunately it is a bit far for me. Otherwise, I'd be here every day without fail. Half sized soba/udon is only $3! Two pieces of inari, $1.50! Best place ever!!

Also, the husband wife team totally kicks butt. I've never waited very long in line. Ford's assembly line should take lessons from them.
author: Angela L.

description: So quick, easy and cheap for lunch. The Udon noodles are delicious, as is the seaweed salad - I can get both for $5! Amazing deal. Run by what appears to be husband and wife, both very efficient so you're in and out! It's great
author: Victoria J.

description: SO CHEAP!! especially if you get the half size portions. I got the half udon and a smoked salmon roll, and my total bill was like, $6. The owners are really friendly and nice, though a little shy and quiet. Food was yums!
author: Melody L.

description:
The only thing I recommend here is the soba or udon soups.  I've had the sushi and it's pretty average - something you can get at a Trader Joe's or upscale Safeway.  However, I'm still giving Yo Yo's four stars because they have a uniquely tasty soup, which I suspect contains msg but it's so good it's worth it. 

The people that run the shop are super nice.  I once didn't have cash on me and forgot my wallet, so they told me to "just owe them for the next time."  That is genuinely good service.

It also takes about one minute to serve up, which is fantastic if you need to grab a quick bite to bring back to your desk.
author: Virginia L.

description:
Quick, cheap, close to work and the portions are just right! 
their Udon soup is delicious....
I love this couple, they are very nice I've been going to them for the past 14 years.
$2.50 for half portions and $4.50-5.00 for a full order of their UDON or Soba soup.
Now, that's a good deal...
author: Claudia E.

description:
this place has charm and really great udon soup. for those qualities alone, they get 5 stars. the sweet couple who run the place are so efficient - they'll take your order and get you out the door within 2 minutes. 

i work in the area, so i love coming here for lunch especially on cold days. the udon soup is only $5 and it's such a generous portion. warms my soul!

i love yo yo's!!

p.s. cash only yo...yo's
author: Krystle I.

description:
One of the best soba noodle soups I've ever tasted (it's a favorite menu choice and I order it out often).  The broth is rich and tasty. Salty? Well, of course it is. That salty goodness drives the flavor of each of the ingredients. If you're salt sensitive, you probably shouldn't eat soups out. 

I can't imagine how anyone could rate this little gem based on their take-out sushi. It's so not the point of the place. I'm not going to rant here, but I challenge the nay sayers to try the soup!

Oh, and not for nothin', but the proprietors are among the nicest people serving food to snotty office workers in the Financial District. There, I said it!
author: Steve J.

description:
First of all, Yelp, what the hell is wrong with you?! Are you trying to kill me?!  This is the second time in 18 hours that you have put me in a food coma.  I think I barely made it back to my office.  I could feel the food coma setting in as I made the 8 or so block walk back to my office.  Ahh, the safety and seclusion of my office.  Close the door, write this review, and find a comfy place under my desk to sleep it off for a while...

That being said, this place is great.  It's crazy cheap. Crazy I tell you.

And crazy good.

I got the full order of Udon soup with everything in it, as well as the addition of tempura and tofu. Yummmmmmy.  The noodles tasted much better than many of the noodle shops I've tried around San Francisco (Suzu, in Japantown, being the best, IMO).  The broth was great.

I also ordered some premade sushi rolls, but I wasn't even able to eat them yet.  They look like the type you'd get from Safeway, so I'm not terribly excited about them. But the soup! Oh my. Fantastic.

I'll be back.  Maybe next time I'll bring a wheelchair.  It was close this time. Too close.  I could have very easily ended up passed out on the street.

One caveat: There is no seating here. Unless you want to sit on the wife's lap. And she seemed really nice, so she might let you if you asked nicely.  It's take-away only.  I enjoyed mine, however, in a park only a block towards the water on Pacific. You can't miss it. And there is a cute water fountain/sculpture to sit near.  There were also a few really cute girls there. I don't know if they'll be there when you go, though. Sorry.

Update: I'm an idiot and just ate some Milano cookies, even after all the talk of the food coma. Owwwww.  I'm screwed once my metabolism dies on me. Now I want milk...How do I get any work done around here anyway? It's Yelp, food, yelp, food, sleep, food, food, yelp, home. I'm a great attorney.
author: Matthew R.

description: Salty salty salty but cheap and so dependable for a good udon or soba noodle soup for lunch!
author: Amy S.

description:
You 'Can't Play with my Yo-Yo' 
don't try to play me out
don't try to play me out! 
Remember that song--it was da' shit--just like this place is. 

One bad thing about having a long holiday break from work is that I actually missed some of my daily lunch hangouts. The good thing is that I was able to visit some long lost places that aren't near my workplace, but still...

Thus, I dedicate my first review in 2009 to Yo Yo's. This place has lifted my spirits when I have been down, fed me when I was close to broke. Thanks to Yo Yo's for great lunches in 2008 and looking forward to many more this year.

I was craving some soba in that yummy broth with seaweed and fresh tofu as I was walking my freezing butt to work this morning. Oh and the marinated squid is sooo good, too. Goes perfect with the noodles.

I've also added chicken teriyaki to my noodles and sometimes grab the edamame for protein as well. The seaweed salad is as good or better than at other Japanese places and it's only $1.25!

Today there was a long line (because it's so damn cold outside) but we got in and out in 10 minutes max. Great price for great food and service!
author: Kat H.

description:
"That will be $4.25, Please."

"for the soup?"

"Everything"

"Did you get my seaweed salad?"

"yes."

"And my drink??"

"yes"

"Holy cow. I think I love you".


As with anything, you have to judge this place for what it is. It is a small (read no tables or chairs, purely take-out) independently owned "mom and pop" type place where a very friendly Mom and Pop are actually the ones that serve you. 

They have limited the menu to a very short list in order to simplify things and speed up service (this place can have a line out the door sometimes during lunch). They specialize in soups and also carry seaweed and calamari salad, a few select sushi rolls, and chicken teryiaki. I have only tried the soup and seaweed salad so I cannot speak for the rest of the food, but this stuff is pretty good. Perfect thing to comfort you if....say, you lost your wallet the night before in a drunken rage and are stressed out and low on funds.
author: Crystal A.

description:
I used to bring my lunch into work to save money and eat healthy.  

Yo Yo's has rid me of that habit and I'm not a big fan of Asian food.

A delicious 1/2 order of Soba plus a 6 piece veggie roll for under $5 served up by some of the nicest people changed me.  I forgot my wallet at the office one day and felt foolish but they told me that it's not a problem at all - pay next time.  

Thank you Yo Yo's - you rock!
author: Jayna B.

description: Cheap.  Fast.  Good.  Perfect for a quick working lunch.  I enjoy the warm soba noodles.  Get there early if you want to be order from the entire menu.  The udon and select sushi rolls sell out.
author: Derek L.

description:
There's a lady in the basement of City Hall that makes the best chicken udon soup ever. That being said, YoYo's udon soup is pretty good. Not quite there, but almost. The broth is a little more oily than I'm used to, and it comes with an inch-thick layer of seaweed and fried tofu on top, unless you ask them to hold it. (City Hall's udon has fresh veggies and not-fried tofu. MMM.) The seaweed is good, though. Mild in flavor and good for you. They're generous with the chicken, too, and it's really very inexpensive. I really like that you can get a half order for just $3.00. (It's more if you add the meat.) And, they let you shake as much chili powder as you want onto the soup, which is key.

Overall, a solid lunch option for financial-district indentured servitude. It's also readily apparent that there are marketing people around (there's a big ad agency on the corner), since the Vitamin Water is flying off the shelves in here.
author: Megan W.

description:
This place is good if you just want to grab something quick and cheap for lunch.  I usually grab two things, and it'll still come out to just $5!

It's a small mom and pop shop, so don't expect a sit-down area.  It's a grab and go joint.

Their menu consist of about 5 things (give or take): udon, soba, teriyaki rice plate, sushi, and side dish (ie: edamame, seaweed salad).

The udon is decent, if you just want some noodle and soup.  The ingredients is nothing fancy.  Just seaweed, noodles, tofu and some fish cake slices.  But it does the job if you want something warm and comforting.

Their sushi is not too great......

I've never tried the seaweed salad, but from all the reviews, it looks like I'll be giving that a try soon.

Nice couple that runs the place.  Very fast and polite.
author: Maggie L.

description:
This is another one of my stops on the "I'm waiting for payday to arrive, but didn't bring lunch to work today" train. Yo Yo's cannot be beat when it comes down to prices for the food.  This is easily one of my fa

The udon is definitely the way to go.  I usually grab a large udon with everything and put a little bit of pepper on it.  When I'm really hungry I'll grab a California roll or something.  The rolls are great, especially for the price and I definitely like to support the little mom and pop versus Safeway down the street.  Plus, the prices are cheaper than Safeway.  Most recently, I tried their chicken teriyaki bowl/plate and I absolutely enjoyed it.  I brought it back to work so that I could eat at my desk (busy day) and 3 people in the office asked what that great smell was and ended up going to Yo Yo's too.

I am definitely a fan of Yo Yo's from the food to the prices and the friendly owners.
author: Ruben P.

description: Bang for your buck....fast and the food is pretty decent considering you can get a pretty filling lunch here for aprons 5-6 dollars. I recommend their soba or udon! The owners are super friendly and don't let the line outside during lunch prevent you from eating here....they move super fast!
author: Tiffamy C.

description:
Yoyo's has a basic menu comprised of: 
-chicken teriyaki (served with a small Japanese-style salad and fruit)
-Udon noodles (options to add tempura, bean curd, seaweed)
-Soba noodles
-sushi (pre-made and packaged)
-seaweed salad (SO GOOD!)

 The portions are big for the full order and you can probably split it between 2 people. The best part is - it's super CHEAP!!! You can come here and spend under $5 for a great fullfilling lunch.

 I'm not a big fan of the teriyaki sauce they use, but I LOVE their udon with bean curd and seaweed. You'll usually find a couple pieces of fish cake in their too! They give you a lot of seaweed and the broth is really yummy too! I also LOVE the seaweed salad - it's really really good. A must-get!!! I'm going back tomorrow!
author: Gladys C.

description: This place is affordable, delicious and friendly - what a great way to start the day :)  I'm a big fan of a half-order of soup.
author: Victor R.

description:
If you are trying watching that waistline like me, and can't afford Jenny Craig, I suggest the Yo Yo's lunchtime diet.

When I don't bring my lunch I just go to Yo Yo's. Even if it's 2 or 3 days in a row, I'll still go to Yo Yo's. It's DIRT CHEAP and so delicious. (The extremely low price makes it taste deliciouser)

For a low-cal but filling lunch :
