Large Soba with Fresh Tofu and extra Seaweed (seaweed has next to no calories btw)

or

Small Soba with Fresh Tofu and extra Seaweed + a seaweed salad / edamame OR a 6-piece veggie sushi.

I rarely spend more than $6 and everything tastes fresh and the husband/wife team are super friendly and they try to memorize your order.
author: Jeannie C.

description: I used to work half a block from this place.  I now realized how spoiled I was now that my office is in SOMA -- the district of no cheap, fast eats.  The couple who owned this place really had their assembly line ordering process down pat.  There's always a line that moves very quick.  You can't beat the soba for the price.  The chicken teriyaki is also great if you're feeling hungrier.  Give them a few visits and they'll remember your usual order ;)
author: Vu N.

description:
So cheap.  So good.  So nice.

Yo Yo's is one of the reasons I miss working in this downtown SF neighborhood.  The udon noodle soup is tasty and hearty with all of the additions of seaweed, bean curd and fish cakes.  I'm a seaweed salad fan and usually had to get that to accompany my soup or pre-made sushi rolls.

I don't know what I would have done without this family run hole-in-the-wall.
author: Sharon R.

description:
Hands Down the cheapest place in the area...the customer service (as other Yelpers have noted) is top notch - the couple that runs the place are so adorable and sweet.

The soup is my favorite - it's all made to order and ToGo only - perfect for grabbing a quick bite to eat.
I wouldn't say that it's the best sushi that I've ever had - but it's much better and cheaper than any grocery store product. 

I've never seen anyone pay more than $5 at this place - but the owners treat you like their most important customer every time.

NOTE: The Udon has a fish based broth...so it's not vegetarian friendly even if you get just Tofu or plain with Bean Curd. 
However, their Tofu Inari is delicious and PACKED full of rice.
author: Katy A.

description:
A $5 (and some change) lunch in the FiDi?? Are you kidding me??

Soba noodles: As the lady in the back said, "it's healthier [than the udon]" and soooo yummy. Crispy tempura things and green onion add flavor to the broth. Fried tofu pieces. Noodles, duh. AND, don't forget your spices! There's a squeeze bottle of spices--ingredients include chili pepper, lemon rind and some other stuff. 

I got a half order (just under $3) and was really full. But, I proceeded to stuff myself with the california rolls (just under $3).
author: Hannah K.

description: Just plain cheap and good. Half an order of udon or soba + 6 piece rolls will only cost about $5. Definitely worth your money here.
author: Jonas T.

description:
i wait in line just to hear mr yo yo ma say SPICY?

I take the open container of soba from him and pause purposefully as he hovers with plastic lid in hand until i have squeezed half his bottle of chili pepper into my soup. spicy? oh yeah.
author: diana m.

description:
I always feel pressured at Yo Yo's, as the owners so pridefully recite my usual back to me when I walk into the shop.  This is great most of the time; especially when I want my usual and love that they remember me as a regular, even when I'm going semi-regularly (insert prune joke here).  It makes me feel special.

Yet some days I want to be exotic. I want to mix it up.  It is then when I'm thwarted by their blurting out a 'half udon, double bean curd' order before I get a chance to say 'I'm feeling the soba today.'  Granted I could tell them to stop filling the soup cup for me but that's far to logical and assertive for my not-yet-soup-fed mind to drum up on the spot.

On the review side - good, cheap, filling, and nice people running the shop.  If you are running late, be prepared to stand in line, but know that it moves fast.

Yo Yo's is a great little hole in the wall lunch spot.
author: Aaron M.

description:
I am so hungover today!  I had a 1/2 order of their udon soup with seaweed, mushy tofu, and tempura batter.  I feel sooo much better. 

I spent $2.25 for that!  Wheee cheapest meal around my work.

The mom n pop show such gracious service and they genuinely are happy when they see their repeat customers.
author: Chris T.

description:
So many positives, wrapped in really cheap prices. A lucky find!
Yo Yo's is only a block from Jackson Park (not sure if that's the name) and is the smallest little place, with awesome udon and soba noodle soups. I tend to get the half-portion of Udon and wakame salad and still come out spending barely 5 dollars. I got the full portion once, and had exactly half left over, so half a portion works perfectly.
They also have sushi, which I haven't tried yet, but is similarly affordable.
The people working there are friendly and very, very fast!
author: Cyrelle D.

description: This place is exactly what it should be. The store is ran by a very nice asian couple that know how to crank out the orders and keep the lines moving. One of the cheapest places in the financial district to get lunch and the food is great! The soba noodles are the way to go. I don't think they are hand made, but the broth and the other ingredients more than make up for it. I would stay away from the teriyaki bowls and stick to miso or soba. The sushi is also extremely cheap, tasty, and fresh. Nothing fancy here though, just standard roll fare; smoked salmon, eel, and california rolls. I have found my new regular lunch spot. Thanks Yo Yo's.
author: Chad B.

description: Great place, and reasonably priced. I recommend the Sobu with everything. Really good. There's sometimes a line, but it moves fast.
author: S H.

description:
The best thing about this place is the nice walk I get from my office on California St.

The second best thing about this place is the wakame salad at $1.75 a pop.

The third is the 1/2 order of Udon(or Soba) for  $2 and some change.

The fourth is 6 piece Cal Roll for $2 and some change.

The fifth is a giant daifuku (I would do anything to sit in a tub of An complete with mochi balls) for $1.25.

5 stars = convenient lunch = dreams of red bean paste mochi bath.
author: Jen I.

description:
The value's tough to beat--for five bucks you get a big steaming "tub" of udon noodles with a few fixings. They also have cold soba (buckwheat noodles), the perfect food for a hot summer lunch. 

Other things they have on the menu: chicken teriyaki (totally skippable); a selection of small bites like seaweed salad, california rolls, smoked salmon rolls, gyoza, and a few sweets like mochi and stuff. 

I love the old couple that runs this place. They're friendly and sweet, and super efficient. They'll have you out the door in less than 5 minutes flat!
author: Jenny P.

description: Stopped by on a rainy day craving some udon. I didn't want to pay the overpriced placed all over FIDI....and was surprised to find this place. Pricing is very reasonable (huge container of udon to go for only $5!), portions are great and the food tastes pretty damn good! Also, the couple who run the place are incredibly nice and efficient. Would definitely go again.
author: Joy B.

description:
When I have a deadline and can't take a lunch, I go to Yo Yo's. It's close by, fast and cheap. It's a small storefront, run by the sweetest couple. 

I usually get their half udon and california roll - and it will only cost you less then $5! What a steal! They also sell Hawaiian cookies - i love the macadamia ones.
author: S N.

description:
Due to the fact that I moved this month, and decided to be a responsible human being and continue my effort pay my bills in full and on time, I found myself low on discretionary funds this week and didn't have time to bring a lunch from home. So I decided to check this place out and see if the yelp reviews would steer me wrong. I'm glad to say the answer is no. I've found that with a lot of Asian food, you have to go by word of mouth, because when it's bad it can ruin your next 48 hours. I got a half order of udon soup, the veggie gyozas and a 6 pc veggie sushi roll for $5.71. (Oh I forgot to mention I was starving today and wanted something in my stomach for a possibly epic happy hour so I wouldn't make a fool of myself in front of my friends and fellow fidi hustlers) . 

It wasn't gourmet by any means. If you're expecting some amazing blow your mind $5 Morimoto creations, you'll be disappointed. But the owners have a great business model: make tasty food quick and cheap; and while yes, you could pile in MickeyDees and eat 12 Chicken McNuggets and down a McMassive Dr Pepper for the same price, here, you at least know you ate something healthy and filling. I found the udon broth to be really flavorful, and the spicy chili powder you can sprinkle on made it yummy. The veggie gyozas were also really good, and by the time I got to the sushi, I was full and didn't even need to eat them (but I did, because I'm puritanical about wasting food). The sushi was my least favorite thing, but it's not like I was disappointed because I was already full and like I said, the udon was yummy and filling. 

I'm so glad I found a cheap, quick lunch place. Like everyone else has mentioned ,the owners are nice and friendly, and you get your food quick and without hassle. Don't be scared off by the line, you'll be in and out of there in no time. 

CASH ONLY!
author: Jennifer O.

description:
EDIT 09/14/07:  I haven't been here in ages, but I work a lot closer to here again, and I've been on a Japanese food kick, so I dropped on by...these have to be the nicest owners around.  I confirmed that the broth in their soup was fish-based, but she was kind enough to fix me up a full veggie meal for only $3.25.  And I've still got other options, like their rolls, seaweed salad, and edamame...their inari is crazy good, and at only 2 for $1.50, it can't be beat.

Pre-made rolls can only be so good, but the service is sweet, food is cheap, and it'll satiate your craving for Japanese - rating bumped to four.

----------------

Yo Yo's is operated through a small storefront on Pacific; if I hadn't found it through Yelp, I'm almost positive it would've been a place I'd pass up otherwise.  It's one of the cheapest restaurants for a meal in the area.  

Stick to the soup (a half-order of Udon or Soba may not seem like much, but it'll last you through the rest of your workday.  But if you've got a hefty appetite, even a full-order is still well under $5 - Note to veggies: double-check that their broth isn't fish based).  The pre-packaged rolls, though also inexpensive, isn't worth it.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
This place is yummy. The udon is fantastic. Listen to the owner and get everything in it. It's so much better than the udon I eat at restaurants. The sushi was alright. Same as other places. The seaweed salad was a delicious. The owners were really friendly. If you plan on coming and eating here, think again. Its a pretty small place so it's more of to go. I like that theres not too much items on their menu, otherwise it would take forever to order. A bad thing is that theres no open or closed time in front of the store. I came again at 4:00pm and it was closed ='[.

For lunch I got  1/2 order of udon, 1 order of udon, 6 pieces of california roll. and a seasweed salad for $11. Super cheap for 2 people. =]
author: Audrey M.

description:
Yo Yo's is a great cheap eats for lunch. A friendly Japanese Couple runs this place with great efficiency. You can get full with just $4 worth of udon or simple sushi rolls. Believe me that it's not easy to find lunch at that price in Downtown SF. 

Too bad I don't work around there anymore. I would go there almost everyday if I could.
author: Bert T.

description: Today is a perfect day for soup noodles. Beware that Yo Yo's is a take out place only so don't expect a sit down restaurant. I ordered the large udon with beancurd and seaweed and a side of seaweed salad yes it came out to around $5. Quick, friendly and good place.
author: Helen Y.

description: Love this place.  Terrific value.  Delicious food.  Great, friendly owners.  I think their udon and soba are the best.  But the gyoza are good too, the sushi (in particular, the veggie sushi) is tasty, and some people swear by the chicken teriyaki.   It's just a hole-in-the-wall so you're taking it back to your desk, or walking over to the park to eat it.   Lines can be long on cold days, right at noon, but otherwise, you can usually get in and out in five minutes.  And I really can't say enough about the couple who run this joint - sweet, friendly, and they always remember what you ordered last time.  Oh, and did I mention it's really inexpensive for the quality?!?
author: Warren B.

description:
Mmmmm... Ridiculously Cheap Udon - Lots of Delicious, Cheap Udon!

I love this hole-in-the-wall, and I've only been once so far.  A friend/co-worker suggested we try it after he read some yelp reviews of the place awhile back.  Since we were coming from near Market and 1st - it was a little bit of a hike for us, but damn was it ever worth it.  

The udon is just so great and filling.  We grabbed full orders (being inexperienced with the massive quantities provided for only $3.50) and then had to struggle to make it back to the office pregnant with newly found lethargy, slothfulness, and contentment.

On my second trip I to Yo Yo's I tried the Chicken Teriyaki, and can report that it is fairly good, and the quantities are great.  Personally, though, I'm just going to stick to the udon.  

Things you should know when preparing your personal pilgrimage to Yo Yo's:  It is cash only, the sushi is terrible (stick to the udon and, from what I hear, the chicken teriyaki), and there is no seating provided (there is however a nice park where you can sit at a fountain while enjoying your soup only a block away).  Personally, I suggest adding both tempura and bean curd to your soup.
author: Matthew H.

description:
The cheapness of the sushi doesn't hide the fact that it's crap. It is the worst sushi you will ever eat. You could make better sushi at home.

To be fair, I haven't eaten anything else there. And I don't intend to.
author: Robert V.

description: The sushi is edible but not very good.  The noodle udon soup is better, but still kind of greasy.
author: Niniane W.

description: Yum for cheap. I used to work around the corner from this place, must have been here at least once or twice a week. They don't really have much sashimi, but a big box of CA rolls and a seaweed salad makes a tasty lunch for mad cheap. Doesn't *quite* fulfill the sushi cravings, but it's darned tasty.
author: Aaron M.

description: Encouraged by Yelpers, I tried this place. I had a large udon with everything. Yes, the owners were super-friendly. Yes, the place was spotless. But the soup was so salty, it was barely edible. I was so disappointed, but I won't be back.
author: Kim C.

description:
Stick with the udon.  After a less than pleasant experience with the chicken teriyaki, I was inclined to return based on cheap prices ($3.60 for 1/2 udon + seaweed salad), quick and friendly service, and the opportunity to spend the afternoon picking seaweed out of my teeth.

All the regulars appear to know how to order their noodles in fancy iterations.  Think it'll take a few more visits for me to catch on.
author: Megan K.

description:
I enjoy the friendly service, the super quick arrival of your udon/sushi/teriyaki and the low prices.  I had the half order of the udon and it was GOOD.  Next time I think I would skip the tempura batter since it didn't really add much to the dish.  I had the CA roll and it was a little mushy.

Looking forward to going again and trying the seaweed salad.  It looks tasty and all the testaments to its powers on these pages makes it a must to try!
author: .Hon H.

description:
One of the cheapest place literally!!! I can't believe they would charge this much for starch and water. I love noodles so I order their Udon. What a big mistake. There were no protein, barely any veggies (if you count the seaweed) and all noodles with miso soup. I could have made that myself.
What a disappointment. However, the service was nice.
Overall, not worth the time or money.
author: A W.

description:
GREAT UDON & SOBA Noodles especially for the price. I always get the half order of udon or soba which is ONLY $2.50. You definitely can't beat that in the Financial district. Also, they have pre-packed California, Smoked Salmon, Unagi & Vegetable rolls. It's descent for pre-packed sushi.
It's ran by a wife & husband who remembers my order every time and even has time to chat when it's so busy. 
Only open M-F 10:30am - 3:30pm. No Seating available.
author: Deb C.

description:
Ok, two things before I review this place
1) Do not get sushi at any place that gets it delivered. In fact, any sushi that has been sitting around is not worth eating. Ever. Hence, stay away from sushi at Safeway, TJ, Whole Foods, etc. Also Yo Yo. I mean, come on people, a lot of it isn't even refrigerated.
2) Stick with things that are hard to mess up and easy to make. The soup here is damn good. 

I got a full order of the buckwheat soup, spiiiiiiicy, and it was damn good. $4.75 for enough food to make a big guy like me feel comatose. I work across the street and imagine I will be eating here again. 

Also, they have some funky Japanese snacks like wasabi edamame and such, big props. There was a line out the door when I got there, but it went super fast because of sushi getting fools (I mean that in the least offensive way possible).
author: Ross G.

description: I prefer to sit down for a meal when I can, but there are those days when I don't have time to take a lunch break away from my desk. In those cases, Yo Yo's is more than I can ask for -- the service is simultaneously super friendly and fast, and the food is absolutely delicious yet cheap.
author: Amy Z.

description:
the udon and soba are so delicious! especially on those cold days.

the seaweed salad isn't too shabby either

the mom and pop are sooooo  nice! which is a total PLUS!

my short quick and dirty review
author: Dorris W.

description: HOLY CRAP. If you're ever in the financial district and are a poor college student, go to Yoyo's! I just got a half order of udon (because I plan to eat later) which includes tempura, fried tofu & seaweed inside, and a good-sized container of edamame for $3.75 total. There's isn't anything particularly special about the food though but what can you expect for getting full off $4?!
author: Sophia L.

description: I absolutely adore this place. Their udon is almost almost as good as my mom's down in LA. The couple behind the counter are super nice, quick and easy on the wallet. I always get the udon with everything. The large size is huge, the half portion goes nicely with some sushi. Perfect for braving a cold San Francisco day.
author: Lisa K.

description: Do yourself a favor and come here on a chilly day with $5 in your pocket. The people here are incredibly friendly, and the udon is fantastic and served fast. It's large enough you could split into two servings.
author: Beth D.

description:
It really doesn't get better than this.  1 roll and 1 order of wakame salad and I walked out with my lunch and my wallet just $3.95 lighter.  It's such a steal.  

Service was fast, efficient and the owners were super nice.  One lady walked in and asked if there were more wakame salad and the lady that worked there apologized and thanked the customer for reminding her to put out more food.  OMG, this type of service in a mom and pop store.  They deserve extra star for that.  

Chicken teriyaki is a bit dry, but the portions are big.  Selection is few, they only have some sushi, wakame salad, chicken teriyaki, udon and soba.  I think that is their entire menu.  But I really can't complain.  It's not like I come here everyday, but once a week, I think I will drop by to have some salad and sushi!!!
author: AhLin C.

description: Just finished my first lunch from Yo Yo's and I'm so glad to have found this place! The food isn't anything fancy, but it's pretty tasty and VERY cheap. I just had a half order of udon with tempura and a california roll, and the total was $5.15. It was a perfect amount of food for lunch and if you're craving japanese of the hole-in-the-wall variety, this is a good place to have on your list. I don't usually like udon, but the broth in their soup was really good. The service was quick, efficient, and very friendly too! Be warned that there is no seating inside and it's cash only.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Right next door to my office, friendly owners, average quality food, and super super super cheap prices.  

Their soup dishes are great for the prices (under $5 for a 1/2 or full size).  They have VERY basic sushi rolls (inari, kappa, california).  It would be more appealing if the sushi packages were placed in a refrigerated compartment instead of sitting out on the counter all day.  It doesn't stop me from ordering the sushi, though-- it's SO cheap and I've never had a tummy ache.  I also love their wakame salad.  It's just as yummy as any gourmet sushi restaurant.  I've never tried the teriyaki, but I'm always in a line of people who can't get enough of the stuff.  

Customer service is impeccable.  The couple who run the place are absolute sweethearts, never make a mistake, and are very speedy!

Writing this review is making me crave some Yo Yo's.   I think I'll grab some for lunch today... toodles!  =)
author: Marilou A.

description: Quick and yummy. I like getting a half order of chicken with green onions. The people who work there are just so damn nice!
author: jennifer r.

description:
More like 3.5 stars. The food isn't all that great (the teriyaki chicken is passable, the sushi boxes scare me a little, haven't yet tried the udon) but the seaweed salad is quite nice. The husband and wife who own the shop are wonderful people who always give me extra things without asking, such as extra spicy and green onions.

But the main reason I love YoYos, the food is dirt cheap.

I went in for lunch and got a teriyaki bento box (half order is more than plenty) which came with copious amounts of rice, a side salad and orange slice. This totaled $3.50. Everything comes in large portions and you can get that and a seaweed salad if you're especially hungry for $5. Working in the FiDi, it becomes very difficult to find affordable places for lunch if you want something hot. This place is less than two blocks away from my work and provides exceptional, lightening fast service with a smile when I need a hot meal.

Review will be updated when I try the udon next time. Good little establishment and much better than the chinese store next door.

Gets knocked down stars because there is no seating and they do not accept credit cards.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
$5 in your pocket and a rumble in your tummy? Fill 'er up at Yoyo's. Cheap- and I mean CHEAP- sushi, noodles, and terriyaki. Both the udon and soba will fill you up- get a half order unless you haven't eaten in days. The soba is a little too sweet for me, but it works when you're hungry nonetheless. 

I usually opt for a seaweed salad and a nine piece sushi tray- its usually California rolls and small unagi and salmon rolls- nothing fancy but nothing you'd be scared to eat raw either. Grab a bottled water from the little snack shop next door (the bottled water is cheaper there) and maybe a cookie, and you're good to go. 

They also have some little Japanese snacks like seaweed crackers, etc here and the couple behind the counter are always beyond friendly. 

TIP: go closer to 2pm or even a tad bit later and sometimes they will upgrade your order or throw in a small side for free before they close up shop.
author: Mindy S.

description: where in the financial district can you buy a decently sized lunch for less than $6?!  it's here.  for $5.25, you can get an order of udon, served with crispy tempura pieces, seaweed, tofu, and a fish cake.  they also have chicken teriyaki, hot/cold soba, and an unlisted special, which includes rice, tempura pieces, seawood, and tofu, topped with teriyaki sauce - $5.  like whoa.
author: Tina L.

description: Super quick, cheap, delicious food. I've had the udon soup ($5.75 for a large), which was great, and sushi (nothing fancy, but for $2.75 you can get a California roll or smoked salmon role with 6 pieces) which was solid. The couple running the place are nice and it's a very quick spot for lunch (usually takes less than 5 minutes).
author: John B.

description: It was a very mediocre meal that I would be satisfied with if I was still in high school. Don't believe the ratings, the price is cheap but so is the food. Very basic and generic. At least it didn't taste bad. Also, it is really just a to-go place. Never again.
author: Sophia K.

description:
Love, love, love this place.  It is a great little place for quick Japanese take-out: soba, udon, etc; especially in the Financial District, which is inundated with high-end expensive long-lunch places.

Price-wise, it does not hurt the wallet - for under $5 one can get an "appetizer" of either edamame or seaweed salad and an "entree" either of noodles, or even a tray of sushi.  

Since it is such a small place, the lines can get long during the lunch rush, but unlike some other places in the city, I find that they don't really run out of food, so even if you go around 1:30P or even 2P - they still have sushi of your choice, noodles of your choice, etc.

The owners are really sweet as well, they remember you if you go in regularly, even try and have your "usual" order ready for you before you even ask.  And unlike some other mom-and-pop joints, prices are listed and stay the same throughout the week.  $2.55 for a tray of salmon sushi stays $2.55 M-F.

Excellent if you are craving some simple Japanese food and don't want to pay too much or wait too long for it.
author: Meghana A.

description: I love you Yoyo's. Good food, nothing fancy but cheap n' good and friendly service.  I've been going there for 14 years now and they've been nothing but good to me.
author: A R.

description:
Love it! Soba noodles always hit the spot. Ask for extra everything! The owners are awesome and if you come often enough, they'll remember your order. It's cheap food without having to sacrifice quality or cleanliness. I don't work around here anymore, but always make it a point to get grub here whenever I'm in the area.

PS - Don't expect to eat in... this place is literally a hole in the wall. A table would take up half the space!
author: Anna V.

description: This is my home for the $6 lunch! Pre-made sushi, but fresh and cheap. Don't be fooled by its small, hole-in-the-wall interior/exterior! The Udon soup with "everything" and the crab rolls are my go to items. The couple that run it are so fast and really friendly. They also have chips, sodas, and things like that as add ons. Its a must in the neighborhood!
author: Natalie N.

description:
I've been to Yo Yos countless times and have never figured out what makes the udon and soba noodle soups so addictive. I've never asked the wife and husband owners of this take-out place if they use MSG but part of me doesn't want to know the answer to that question. 

Yo Yos is the best "bang for your buck" for lunch. The only other place with a better deal is Subway and we all know how that can get old fast... I would recommend getting the Udon soup without tempura as it gets soggy in the soup and any of their rolls. Don't expect the best sushi ever but for a soup and sushi combo of $5, you really can't complain! They also have wakame salad, chicken teriyaki and a decent assortment of drinks and japanese snacks.
author: Lan H.

description: The soba and udon are the BEST in San Francisco!  And the husband and wife who own and operate it are amazing!  Friendly, positive and FAST.  I've never had another $5 lunch in SF that takes less than 5 mins.  And I'm always full after eating!
author: A T.

description: I went to Yo Yo's for the first time yesterday, and I'll be going back today. And quite possibly tomorrow. What more can I say? It's both delicious and inexpensive, a rare combination in the Financial District.
author: Erica W.

description: This place is amazing! Cheap, delicious, filling, and incredibly kind owners to boot. I'm hooked; looks like I'l be here at least weekly for my lunches here on out!
author: Cathy B.

description:
I got a 1/2 order of the soba noodles (comes with bean curd, noodles, seaweed, and some fried soy beans (looks like rice crispies)).  I also ordered an order of seaweed salad. Both came out to 4 bucks or something ridiculous like that.  Definitely will be on my list of regular places to go for lunch since it's across the street from work!  :)

If you're a smaller person like me, I think the 1/2 order of the noodles will do just fine.  If you are big (or not petite), the full size noodles would be more suitable.  

I didn't touch the sushi based on questionable reviews here, but my co-worker got the teriyaki chicken and judging from what was left of her meal, it was pretty tastey.  It's not going to be the best meal ever in your life, but it's so cheap...how can you lose?
author: Quyen T.

description:
The owners are so friendly and fast! Im not so into the soups so I just got one of those pre-packaged rolls...I think it was California, Salmon and one other one with chicken I think...all were very tasty.

Im a glutton for edamane. They give you good portions and are so cheap! $5 for a filling sushi meal!
author: Erin F.

description:
Yo yo is fantastic. The couple that runs the place is so amazing and precious, even if I disliked the food I'd still come by for lunch everyday. (Which by the way, I don't. Love the food.) Or consider writing my will out to them had I not a spouse and a child. (I don't.) It's a teeny shop, to-go only. Precious soba noodles, inari, teriyaki, maki sushi, edamame... 

Aside from feeling like I am coming home to my momma's home cookin' if only for a moment, I think this might just be the place that'll help me drop my ever-growing middle-aged tire. That's right. I'm Asian and I have a fat tire. Won't you still love me anyways?
author: D'arcy N.

description: I work a few minutes away from Yoyo's, and it's a go-to lunch spot. I typically get a half udon and either edamame or seaweed salad, but there are many other varieties you can get for a good price. The couple who runs it is fantastic!
author: Emily L.

description:
Okay...you got to have some perspective when you go to this place. If you work in FiDi then you know good cheap meals isn't always easy to find. 

This place has a little bit of variety and prices that you can live with. The owner are nice and remember your order if you come on a regular basis. 

Make sure to go after the lunch rush. Sometimes they will make you sushi fresh when it is slow.
author: Nikki L.

description: Hungry-at-an-odd-time-of-day-and-don't-feel-like-spending-a-lot-of-money place to go. Satisfied.
author: Deb B.

description: Yo Yo's is a great take-out lunch place for Udon. The service is great and the food is tasty. Very simple, fresh, and satisfying. The red chili powder is really yummy, I always dump a healthy amount on my Udon before heading out. You can't beat the price, either.
author: Ben C.

description: They have cheap sushi that actually is quite good.  Udons and Chicken teriyaki are very good and cheap.  Alot of food for the money.  Their drinks are also less than the deli next door and the Hot Wok down Battery.  Come here in the morning and get some sushi for breakfast.  It's great!
author: Kevin L.

description: not bad, but not great. since i've been in this area for my job, finding food has been a challenge!!! there is not much here, which was depressing. i really missed cafe tomo (which had closed down) and wanted some sort of japanese noodle soup. i heard yoyo's may have something to offer, but it was not what i was looking for.
author: Marjie T.

description:
Cheapest, quickest lunch in the area. I usually go for a 1/2 order of udon with tofu, tempura, and fishball slices and 6-piece pack of sushi, and it's under $5.

Seaweed salad is also good.

UPDATE: I think some of the reviews are for Yo Yo, the sushi place in the Mission. Yo Yo's, the lunch place on Pacific, doesn't have a salmon teriyaki. http://www.yelp.com/biz/o0IXUSQ7B462cghcAwZrlw
author: Stacy J.

description:
After living in Hawaii for 5 years I consider my self a connoisseur of soba and udon. I've had it in almost any imaginable way, shape, and form. I prefer traditional w/not too many distractions.

Yo Yo's is the most authentic place I've had udon/soba in the city so far. With two choices on the menu, full and mini, and the option of going hot or cold for the soba. You basically get noodles, tofu, fried tofu, bean curd, kamaboko (fish cake for the noobs), seaweed, and scallions. You have the option of adding chili flakes and/or wasabi before they package it all up. For $4.50 you can't go wrong w/a fresh noodle soup that's really delicious too! If you want, they also have sushi and chicken teriyaki on the menu too. I say just go for the noodles though.

Yo Yo's is definitely on my short list of consistently reliable lunch establishments in the Financial District. I shall return.
author: Gary T.

description:
Talk about a lunch time deal. For about $5, you can grab yourself a "full order" chicken teriyaki meal that will hit the spot. This place also has an assortment of pre-made rolls and a pretty mean seaweed salad. I can do this place practically everyday and who wouldn't with that great couple running the place. A two person team, the owners seem like genuine people who keep the place lively with upbeat conversation and that oh-so-good feeling of knowing your name and/or order before you can say a word. I am more then happy to pitch my $5 in for  this family business. 

Drawbacks? For a quick cheap pick up lunch, not much can be said to downplay this place. It is what it is.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description: Yo Yo's is awesome!! In an area where the cheap lunch options are limited, Yo Yo's saves the day all the time. Thanks Yo Yo's!
author: Ru C.

description: These people are amazing!  Not only are lines super fast, the food is great!  Not to mention the prices are extremely reasonable!  Hope this place stays around forever!
author: Joseph C.

description:
Tempted to give this little hole-in-the-wall a try, after reading various reviews on yelp. Ordered a 6-piece sushi consists of 2 smoked salmon rolls, 2 cali rolls, and 2 unagi rolls-- all for just $2.45
The portion is just right for a girl who needs a light lunch, and I must say, the sushi is not bad at all.
Since I didn't try anything else on the menu, I'm giving it a 3-star first.
Look for my reviews in the upcoming months...
author: Joy H.

description:
$3.50 udon and I couldn't even finish it- that's hard to beat. Made it totally worth walking an extra few blocks than I usually do for my lunch. Definitely ask for the tempura batter. Didn't try the sushi but a co-worker said it wasn't all that bad.

I always give extra stars for good service and this is no exception- the owners are adorable.
author: Mariah K.

description: Great prices, friendly and very quick service, and solid food earn Yo Yo's four stars in my book.  The food is solid.  It's not the best udon or sushi that you'll find, but it's very good for the low prices and friendly/efficient service.  In case you haven't been here before, it's pretty much just a take-out restaurant.  Great for a quick to-go lunch.
author: Jason L.

description: Sometimes I dream of Yo Yo's on the weekends and it's a bummer they are only open during the weekdays. Though not the most excellent or amazing bowl of hot noodle soup, the incredible value makes it an easy go-to place for lunch. The line can get pretty long during the usual lunch hours, but the couple who run this place are food service efficiency at its best. The menu isn't too extensive, but they are more than willing to accommodate any funky twists on their menu items.
author: NickJess S.

description: I'm totally obsessed with Yoyo's which is weird because I don't feel like the food blows me away, but it's fast, inexpensive, and incredibly satisfying. The couple that runs the place assemble my order with lightning speed and are always so kind to me. I want to adopt them as an extra set of parents.
author: Clarissa S.

description:
Cheap grub.  Udon and sushi ranges between $2-$5.  
Comfort food.
Sushi however are definitely on the generic side.  The salmon they use in the rolls are smoked salmon, which isn't my liking exactly.  If you end up getting a big pack of sushi there, like 9-12 pieces, you're better off going to safeway and buying a pack there, because you get more bang for the buck.  And it'll taste better too.
author: Emily L.

description:
If you want an Easy, No Frills, To-Go  Great Sushi spot...this is your place!
I used to work at CBS and I would eat here almost every day!
The seaweed salad is grub, I was queen of the veggie roll.
On the foggy days, the Udon isn't to be missed.
Its a prefect pick up your lunch and head back to your desk.
Be warned the selection isn't HUGE, and that this isn't Sushi Grove. There isn't even a table to sit at inside. 
Also, It is cash only!
but its the Best for what you get.  In a world where sushi is simply...OVER PRICED!  At Yo Yo's they keep it real. 
oh yeah...ps. The owners have to be Two of the Nicest People I know!
Now that I don't work in that area I miss it every day :(
author: Whitney K.

description:
Be careful that you don't mix up Yo's Sushi Club and Yo Yo's. If you have a frequent diner card from Yo's, just use the phone number on the card. 

Yo's is a solid sushi place on Mission near 30th. I've heard that people have been mixing up the two and placing a carryout order at one and then showing up at the other. I also see potential for people mixing up the reviews.  

YO is the Japanese owner and sushi chef at Yo's Sushi Club. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz/Dbd0PT3dXqSAffjTPOUnzg#hrid:3G63zUoiKSAV1v1nuYtYfg/query:yo's
author: Marina N.

description:
Decent food for the price.  I like the cold soba, with a wakame salad and a pack of edamame, which total around $5.  I tried the chicken teriyaki, which I found blecchy (chicken with teriyaki sauce squirted on it),and have since stuck to the noodles.  

Theres usually a line but it moves fast.
author: Mia G.

description:
Have you ever been intrigued by a restaurant because there's a line out the door? So you wind up putting it on your "to try list" to see exactly why it's so popular. Regarding Yo-Yos, I still haven't figured out why people are willing to stand in line. Possibilities: 1) I guess because it's cheap people are willing to sacrifice taste 2)  they're lazy like me and can't walk to Myth a block down to get something gourmet 3) The cool affect: I'm cool because I'm waiting in line at a hole in the wall sushi shack. How hip of me.

I'll be honest. I've tried everything they have to offer multiple times because I'm lazy and my office is right there but I would never wait in line and only go when I can squeak in at non-peak times. The noodles are so-so, and within minutes I can feel the MSG coursing through my veins. The sushi isn't great and I'm not one to risk eating bad sushi. . Basically, if you want a cheap meal, go next door to Silverstar. If you're after noodles, I think you can pick up a box of Top Ramen for $1 at Safeway 4 blocks away if you want something cheap.
author: Nicole C.

description:
great deal, friendly couple who owns it will remember you if you go enough.  Its just so cheap.  and so filling.  Great on a cool day to take to the park and warm youself up under the sun with a steaming miso broth.  
"you like spicy?"

1 downside is the teriyaki bento isn't as good as sushi bay on kearny.

but the soba and udon are fantastic!!
author: Christian W.

description:
This place is wonderful!!! The couple who runs the little store is always friendly, and the prices are so amazing! 
They have soba or udon noodles (which you can add tempura bits, tofu, seaweed, or chicken to) in two sizes...a half order is usually pretty filling already! 
Also they have chicken teriyaki (which I've never tried), some seaweed salad and assorted sushi rolls.
I always get a half order of soba with everything and california rolls!!!!! A delicious lunch for an excellent price.
author: Emily H.

description: my boss and I have lunch dates once a week or so and this is one of our favorite hidden gems. He used to come here back when he worked at KGO and said we had to go back and say hi to his "girlfriend" (the nice lady who works the counter/soup). The owners are so sweet and remember what we like everytime which earns a star in itself. They have SUPER cheap delicious udon which  is great for all the cold/windy/rainy days San Fran is known for. They also have 6 and 9 piece sushi, yummy calamari salad and seaweed salad, and I like the chicken teriyaki box (3.25 for a small order). Definitely high up on my lunch list and I am always super stuffed after my lunch from Yo Yo's.
author: Sarah A.

description: best udon and soba ever! quick, cheap and easy...what more could one want?!
author: Ricquel N.

description: Recent discovery and love the people who work there.  Sweet, fast and work hard.  I've had the udon and chicken teriyaki.  They were just on channel 7 news because of the exorbitant health insurance fees they need to pay.  So go there to help them.  It's real tough selling good, affordable food and yet paying thousands a month for health insurance.  Your tummy'll thank you and so will the workers.
author: Emm C.

description:
This is Yo Yo's;
* under $5
* extremely hard working staff that remember what you ordered last time.
* it's okay if you're short money -they trust you to repay later.
* tasty food
* simple menu

If you reuse the plastic containers, you will see a twinkle in their eyes : )
author: Morty P.

description:
Lunch for me is usually diet coke and almonds at my computer.  Three or four times a year I grab lunch at Yo Yo's.  There are some mornings where I don't even recognize myself in the mirror yet when 
I make an infrequent appearance they not only me and my order, but they also remember that my office mate gets her udon spicy with double tofu.  

The food at Yo Yo's is perfect lunch fare; consistent, healthy, and affordable.
author: Tom D.

description:
Great lunch for under $5:
-1/2 Chicken Teriyaki with Seaweed salad
-1/2 Chicken Teriyaki with 1/2 Udon (or Soba) noodles

I also verify all previously mentioned positive remarks (extremely friendly husband and wife, great chicken teriyaki, delicious udon & soba noodles, inexpensive).  There is sometimes a wait during peak lunch hours, especially on cold days, but really any decent food near the financial district has a wait at least this long at lunch hours.
author: Morgen N.

description:
Why is it Mrs. Yo Yo always remembers my exact order of big udon with everything minus tempura, yet Mr. Yo Yo can never remember it's a "no" for the spicy spice. Yep, she is definitely the brains behind this operation.

Thanks to the yelper who suggested adding the chicken to your soup... I'm trying that fo sure next time.

Oh... anyone have any insight to the "Warning: this food may cause cancer" sign in the corner by the window??
author: Cowbella H.

description:
Wow. Discovering this place is going to be a big plus in my lunchtime artillery. It's so cheap here I can barely stand it. The food is tasty, though in no way gourmet, but really what can you expect for a super fast, uber cheap meal in between meetings at work. Their udon is pretty tasty, and a half order will cost you two bucks!! (The half order is plenty to feed me, though I guess I am a short girl type person. But I can eat, I swear!!)

Convenient and with a super nice couple behind the counter, I don't even think it's possible to go wrong.
author: Tara O.

description: Food is not bad, and oh so cheap!  Udon noodles for $2.25?! Craziness...
author: Andrea W.

description:
a great lunch spot for the cold string of days we've had in the bay area for a great price.

the menu is pretty small but very good.  either you can get soup w/ udon, soup w/ soba (hot or cold) or chicken teriyaki.  for any of the dishes, either a full or half order can be ordered.  i've only had the soups and the half order is plenty and cheap, around $2.50 - $3.

w/ the soups you can add seaweed, tofu and/or tempura.  the tofu is so nice and soft and is actually a pleasure to eat.  the broth is lovely and i guess can be described as full of umami.  the noodles are cooked well no matter which you pick.  i haven't tried the cold soba nor the chicken teriyaki but will do so soon.

also, this place reminds me of a soup version of good luck cafe.  both have a lil asian couple running the tiny story, both are super fast and both are very affordable!
author: Swarup B.

description:
I've had the sushi rolls and they are very good for the price, I go here for that about once a month since I work a block away. 

The chicken teriyaki is stomach turning, I bought it once and threw it away after two bites, it tastes as bad as it looks...

Funny thing is about this place is I feel like I'm on that episode of Seinfeld with the Soup Nazi... everything is so quick, when you get to the front of the line you will have paid and have your bad in like 5 seconds, it's really something to see, it's kinda worth the trip by itself... whenever I got I try to be quick with my money so I don't get banned.
author: Adrian H.

description:
I checked this place out on lunch today and I was pretty happy all around.  It's so very, very cheap and the quality is pretty good.  I got a half order of soba with tofu and seaweed, and one California roll, which they make WITHOUT MAYO, so they are my new heroes.  

All this for a grand total of $5.35 - I will definitely be back.  

The only reason that they get 4 instead of 5 stars is that the sushi is sitting out on the counter.  It's was still cold when I got there at noon, but I wouldn't try it after 12:30 or so.  I just have this weird concept that raw fish should be kept refrigerated, call me crazy.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Savory udon noodles, 6 pieces of scrumptious sushi and a pomegranate tea for $5, all prepared by some of the nicest people in San Fran -- I'm sold.

Special considerations for future Yo Yoers:

--Cash only!!

--If you are a sushi nazi this may not be the place for you. The sushi is pre-made and sits in a fridge on a plastic wrapped paper plate. 

--The hot garlic salt they offer for the udon is drain your sinuses hot!!  

--This is a teensy, bare-bones noodle shop. If you are paying less than the cost of a round trip ticket from SF to the East Bay for great food who gives a shit about the decor or lack of tables? If you need atmosphere go to Yo Yo's on a beautiful day and take your lunch to the cute little park down the street.
author: Emily D.

description:
California roll + half order of udon + seaweed salad = $6.10!

I heart you, Yo Yo's.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Great Cheap lunch food.  Not much on the menu but great stuff.  

You can't beat a $3.50 lunch.  You get a huge Udonor Soba noodle with all the trimmings.

You need something quick and easy this is the palce to go.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Pros:  Very affordable, great noodles, cheap sushi rolls.
Cons:  Acute fragrance, they keep the skin on the chicken.
author: Eric S.

description: Tried the Udon and loved it. Broth has great flavor. Perfect meal for a cold day. Reasonably priced. The spinach gyoza is also good.
author: Gary W.

description: Great value for their food. Their menu is very basic: they primarily serve sushi rolls (california, tuna, unagi, avocado, cucumber), udon, soba, and chicken teriyaki rice plates.  This place is run by a husband and wife team who are very personable. They make the effort to remember customers' names, along with their usual orders. I love patronizing them because of their service along with the value of their food.
author: Grace G.

description:
I love Yo Yos
I go there veryday for lunch!
they are so sweet
I feel like they are pretty much my family.

The sushi is delicious
the Soba and Udon is the best.
Very Cheap
Great customer service
they make jokes
I couldn't live without you guys.

I just wish you were open on weekends.
Serisously

In Conclusion,

Nobel peace prize
author: Ramoose T.

description:
The obvious bonus of Yo Yo's is the price. A solid lunch for under $4. I've eaten everything they have, which is easy since the menu constists solely of chicken teriyaki, soba & udon, edamame, calimari salad, seaweed salad, and about four different styles of rolls. 

Lydia and Joseph do an amazing job of getting a crowd of people fed with warmth and a very genuine "Thank you for coming."
author: Chris J.

description:
The husband and wife always greets me as "Richard's Brother".  I get a large udon soup with seaweed and tofu packets every time, and maybe one of their generic California rolls.  Sometimes I go there a few days straight, and I get pretty regular for that week with all that roughage.  Now that they open at 8:00am, I can have a hot breakfast regularly.

Why the four stars?  Because I can eat their fast-food udon noodle soup three times a week for cheap, and I don't get tired like everything else.  I'll my friends here but I won't get mad if they don't like it.
author: Amanibhavam K.

description: This is the most friedly lunch spot I have ever found. Their deals cannot be beat. $4.50 for a HUGE lunch? Lydia, a co-owner, is  always is slipping me an extra sushi roll for lunch. And Joe is so nice! I will continue going here for their delicious Udon as often as possible.
author: Douglas C.

description:
It's affordable...9 pieces of sushi for less than $5. Their lunch plates are huge! 

The quality was so bad though. I personally thought that sushi from Safeway might be better and I usually get them as a last resort.
author: Judy D.

description: If you can bitch about yo yo then you have  serious problem with life and living.This small island of harmonius energy posing as a japanese takeaway stand is a soothing balm for the working wounded down in the financial dist.The prices are all ridiculously low and what they do they do so very well.Udon-excellent,half or large size,Soba-excellent,half or large size.chicken teriyaki at its soy sugary bestness.All manner of maki and octopus or seaweed salads to help even it all out for a great little lunch that will have you smiling for the rest of your day.The folks who run the place must be up for sainthood I think.they are a delight ,all from the heart,even the food.
author: eamonn d.

description:
yay! day #3 on my quest to find cheap lunch spots near my office was a resounding success!  

I searched for "cheap lunch" in the financial district and way at the top was Yoyos  (am I the only one who has never heard of this place?)   I dragged a co-worker there who seemed relatively intrigued.  The place is tiny - like smaller than my office tiny - but you can tell everything is so fresh & homemade.  

I got a half order of the soba noodles and had the choice of seaweed, tofu (skins or fresh) and tempura.  I also got a small 6 piece of mixed sushi.  A quick squirt of chili powder into my noodles, and I was out the door in less than 5 minutes!

Total bill: $4.95.  And, I'm completely full, happy, and wondering if it is too soon to return tomorrow.

On a totally separate note: the take-out bowls they serve your udon in are dishwasher & microwave safe!  i'm definitely taking mine home in the off-chance I ever decide to actually bring lunch to work.
author: Lisa R.

description:
Total staple for the Jackson Square worker bees.  The couple that runs this very small to-go sushi/udon place is extremely friendly, welcoming and really cranks through the line you'll inevitably wait in at noon.  They are on it.  

You will crave this place.    I get the same thing every time.  Vegetarian pre-wrapped rolls.  Simple easy.  Co-workers get the udon with the works.  

It is cheap.   Go between 11-2.  They close in mid afternoon.
author: Smilingspiders C.

description:
When it's 3pm and i realise my multitude of brainfarts are likely due to the fact that i haven't eaten yet, i take the elevator out of my office and go next door to Yoyo's.
Not a sit-in type of place, more of a pick-up sort, super fast service, dirt-cheap. 
I eat here at least once a week. Mrs. Yo is always dressed in smiles, recognizes me, and if the place doesn't have a huge line will chat me up about her day.
so far the udon is my favourite [$2.5 for a half order usually fills me up], although the soba, calamari and seaweed salad are good too. i've not yet tried the sushi or the teriyaki. 

I'm not sure if she does this with everyone but mrs. Yo often throws in extra things for free, today i got inari. maybe i am just a great tipper, but she sure does make me feel special.
author: talaitha d.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE! The cute husband and wife duo that run this rather small (almost soup nazi like) place are so nice. If you go often enough they give you a "little extra" haha.  

Limited Menu- i suggest going for the half chicken terriaki! yum!
author: Terry C.

description: I want to add to the chorus of "Hell Yes" for Yoyo's.  The food is solidly good, service is very quick and friendly and the prices are great.  One tip, there is a hidden veggie option-called the vegetarian special-that gets you all the soup toppings over rice with a salad on the side.  The soup is a fish broth, if that ends up being something that bothers you.  This is my lunch treat, love the couple who runs this, coming back soon.
author: Paul W.

description: i found this place from yelp and by the comments people made, it seemed like a cheap place to have lunch. I ended up getting just a seaweed salad cuz i already had lunch that day. To my big surprised, it only costs $1.35..and the portion was decent. I saw their posted menu inside the shop and the prices were unbelievably cheap. I have to come back for lunch one day and see if the food exceeds my money's worth.
author: Bon T.

description: Really wanted to like this place and support the mom and pop business, but food was very disappointing. Yes, it's cheap. You get what you pay for. Udon noodles were  overcooked and mushy. Did not like the tempura batter crumbs. I also tried the vegetable dumplings which were cold, soggy and not tasty.
author: RK L.

description: excellent cheap lunch in the fidi.  Mom & Pop shop - very well run.
author: Jasper D.

description: My favorite lunch spot in the financial district. Hands down. It's the cheapest, tastiest lunch option in the area. I love the soba and udon soups, love the $1.65 six pack of avocado rolls, and LOVE the service. They always thank me for coming in, and I'm always happy I did. Don't forget to try the insanely cheap seaweed salad too.
author: Elke B.

description: Quick and yummy udon noodle soup! The large noodle soup (with everything) is tasty and don't even miss the fact that there is no meat! Also picked up a 6-piece sushi roll (california and unagi) - all this for $7. I will definitely be a regular! Service was super fast and friendly.
author: Joy A.

description: Just discovered this gem! Super good, super cheap food!!! Don't walk away just because there is a line! They are super fast! And cash only! I will be here several times a week!
author: Phil B.

description:
I don't eat at yoyo's too often and yet every time I come here Mr's Yo somehow remembers exactly what I want. She makes me feel important the second I walk in the door. And I can't forget Mr Yo.; he is quick and friendly with his instructions: "Spicy?" is all he usually says, but it's enough. They let you know they genuinely appreciate your business every time you come here. 

I forgot the food. The udon and soba both are ridiculously good; get extra bean curd, you won't be disappointed . The tofu-rice ball thing and edamame are delicious. The teriyaki chicken is also good. Surprisingly the sushi is also good, but seriously people, don't complain that you don't like your roll when it costs like $1.50. It's not going to be super great, use a little common sense. Oh did I mention Yo's is ridiculously inexpensive. 

Come here for lunch if you work nearby. Seriously.
author: will s.

description: This is hands down the best deal in the city. Half an order of udon for $2?? I can have that and 6 unagi rolls for less than $5 and I'm definitely full. I've gotten a full order of udon at another japanese restaurant and it was almost $8!! The full order of udon at yoyos is half that price. It's a bit far from the fidi, but I get to walk through Jackson Square to get there and eat my udon outside in the park.
author: stephanie l.

description:
Today, I ventured a few blocks further from my office in an effort to find a new lunch haunt - preferably one that set me back less than $10 (oh, but I still love you, Mixt Greens). As luck and Yelp would have it, Yo Yo's exists.

I took a hint from everyone else and ordered the Udon - plus fresh tofu. Can anyone explain to me how something that costs $4.50 is so filling and delicious? I will probably get the half order next time. The amazingly sweet couple that owns the place were delightful, so I decided to get something else, too - green-wrapped vegetarian potstickers of some kind. Super good. 

Long story short? I am a happy camper. You will be, too.
author: Amanda D.

description: I work over near Moscone and there is a Japanese restaurant downstairs that sells teriyaki and udon to go.  Their prices are crazy and the portions suck.  What a refreshing change when you walk into YoYo's!  It is amazing!  For a much larger portion and only at $3.50 I get a full quart of Udon soup with everything.  The broth has the right amount of sweetness and added to that are tons of noodles, seaweed, tempura and if you want bring up the heat with the spicey powder.  I tried the seaweed salad for the first time.  It was amazing. I used to work at Roxanne's Raw in Larkspur (now closed) and it compares to that and is a fraction of the price.  Do yourself a favor, walk there at lunch and you will be fulfilled for $5.00!
author: Scott P.

description: I went to Yo Yo's for the first time today. Upon hearing I am a vegetarian, the wife offered to make me a custom bento box with a bed of rice, teriyaki sauce, tempura, boiled/steamed seaweed, and cold tofu and yo-tofu (the sweet saucy fried tofu). This wasn't on the menu. It costs me $3.25.  I have finally stumbled across a keeper-vegetarian-lunch spot in the financial district.  Thanks for the recommendations, fellow yelpers!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
little hole-in-the-wall japanese place. unfortunately it's only open a few hours a day during the lunch rush. and don't let the long lunch lines scare you. that should tell you how great this place is. cheap and good sushi, chicken teriyaki, yakisoba and soup.

there's nowhere really to sit, so you'll have to take your food to the park (two blocks east) or back to work. but the staff are ridiculously friendly. if you work in this part of town and haven't eaten here, you're missing out.
author: Johnny H.

description: always does the trick!! perfect place for a 5min $5 lunch!! there is often a line of regulars out the door...but the nice asian couple who run the joint work it like a well-oiled machine!!! they make the bbeessstttt INARI,  i think the secret ingredient is luuvvv! their cali rolls are decent and satisfying...havent had the balls to try the udon yet....but believe me i will!  and thats pretty much it!
author: Kaylan S.

description:
cheap and instant gratification = a good meal in a pinch.  i've been coming here for years, and nothing much has changed, you know what to expect, and that's a good thing. and they know me by now, so you get that nice mom'n'pop feel that's often lacking in this world!

pretty much everyone already said it all in previous reviews - very small, no seating, line out door (good sign), limited menu, prem-made sushi (this ain't no sushi zone or yum yum fish, but fine of the price), udon and soba soup and cold soba noodles, chicken teriyaki, seaweed salad, octopus salad, wasabi peas, and two of the nicest people running the place.  you can get whole or half orders of soba or udon soup (if you want everything in it, this includes seaweed, bean curd, and tempura batter) - i always get half w/ everything and sprinkle that amazing hot stuff on it.  i usually get out of there for under $5 (and about $3.50 w/out a drink).  

they are open till 4pm - sometimes i go so late, they throw in some extra sushi...its a great quick fix when you're on a tight budget.
author: Suzanne A.

description: Horrible - you ingrates have no taste buds.  Nor do you have any idea what Japanese food should taste like.
author: Will H.

description: Cheap and delicious!  I can't say that it's the best udon or soba you'll ever have, but it's definitely the best value for the money.  Top that with a super cute couple running the shop, and you've got a winner!  :)
author: Fontane L.

description: Don't go to some chi-chi California-cuisine bistro sandwich cart for lunch. You can get full here for $2, and you can become a fat ass for $3.50. Their udon is yummy, their chicken teriyaki is good, and they whip out your order in less than a minute.
author: Ben P.

description: Such a great place for a quick lunch.. in fact I really miss it since i am no longer in the area.  The soba and udon are super yummy and really cheap.  My favorite (which I really miss) is the cold soba.. it is soooooo good and instead of the chili mix that they use to spice the hot soba, they put a dollop of wasabi in it!!! yuuuummmmmmmm
author: mel m.

description: Yo Yo's is a cheap and fast place to grab a japanese lunch if  you work by the financial district.   I think their food is just okay, nothing to rave about.  Their soba and udon noodle soups are pretty decent.   I would stay away from their sushi, it taste like it was made at least the night before.
author: Lily T.

description: Got lunch here with a friend on a cold day that called for some steaming udon. I like the puffed rice or whatever it is that comes on top, but otherwise it's unremarkable (yet not at all bad) food. For the price, it's a solid option, but I got hungry soon afterward. Also, this place is takeout only--we got literally the only two seats in the place when we went.
author: Angela X.

description:
This is my first review and its long overdue. Jo and his wife's tip jar--

Everyday, YoYos
Today Again So...
Tomorrow--Who Knows? -Jo

--was my inspiration! This duo is adorable and ever-friendly.  They remember my order everytime, and the "noodles" are so good.  The perfect hole-in-the-wall spot for a soup pick-me-up on a cold day (or to-go-sushi on a  warm one)! 

Sushi, seaweed salad, unagi, edamame, green tea cakes, udon, soba, chicken terriyaki--full and half orders! :o)
author: Stevie B.

description: Had lunch here yesterday with an ex-FiDi regular and got some delicious soba noodles with everything in it. I recommend sprinkling a hefty amount of their chili powder that they have on the counter. My friend and I grabbed the only two seats and table available because we were too tired to walk to the park, but the generous helping of noodles gave me my second wind after a long day of shopping! I'll definitely be back in the near future and become one of those regulars they remember the names of.
author: Anna Y.

description:
mr. and mrs. yo have saved me from countless hangovers with their miracle broth.  reminiscent of in-n-out, their secret menu doubles your options (hint: ask for jeremy's special).  

essentially, yo yo's is like all the comfort of coming home... to my (questionably) japanese mother and father...  except that they don't yell at me, and i can wear my shoes inside when i come home.  win win.
author: Mooni P.

description: Oh dear, you are only within a minute walk from the place I work. How you two both husband and wife has served me on the days where I'm too hung-over to pack lunch or eat solid foods. I love to order either full udon or wheat with of very course EVERYTHING. If only chained and served from a rain shad like they serve it in Japan, you would be the next ubuck helping the nightlife of the young hip hop scene swarming America. To say the least, what great instant noodle you serve. Arigato Gozaimasu
author: Harry L.

description: I don't know why I keep coming here.  The broth is way too sweet, and they put way too much seaweed in my udon.  Well, maybe it's because I'm way too cheap.
author: K N.

description:
If I could give this 4.5 stars, I would. The only thing keeping me from making this 5 is because they are not open on weekends. 

CASH ONLY.

Delicious soups (I've only had the hot Udon and Soba) and the price is more than right. Perfect on a day like today, when it is rainy, cold and miserable outside. You can add tofu! Today's lunch: $2.70 for half hot udon with tofu. 

Can't beat that.
author: Amanda S.

description: At first I was pretty pumped to find a new lunch spot in the area. Great bang for buck compared to other local spots. But it didn't sit too well with me afterwards. The little balls floating on the top of the soba soup? Those are tempura balls. They will give you a stomach ache. Going to give it another go with just soba, seaweed and tofu with no extras and see how it goes!
author: Sarah R.

description: I love the couple who runs this joint and I also love the food. The sushi is so reasonably priced (no, it's cheap) and the soba is also delish.
author: Sasha S.

description: I eat lunch here almost every day. Great, fresh food. A friendly couple runs this extremely fast take-out restaurant. there is almost always a line out the door, but it goes fast. I usually alternate between 1/2 order soba or a 1/2 order chicken teriyaki. The food is also extremely cheap. I usually eat for $3. Not kidding.
author: Prasant R.

description: I tried this place today with some coworkers who have gone there.  I scanned the Yelp reviews in advance, to have an idea what to expect.  Well, I expected a hole in the wall, but I was surprised that the place is very clean and not at all run down or anything.  It is small, so maybe technically a hole in the wall!  But not the run down or dirty type place that implies.  The couple were both very friendly.  I am vegetarian and asked if the broth was veggie.  The broth is fish-based.  I asked if the cold soba noodles are veggie.  No, they are cooked in the same broth.  But the lady was nice and took some of the other soup ingredients and put then on rice to make a veggie meal for me.  How nice!  It was white rice, some kind of sauce, green onions, tempura batter, plus seaweed and bean curd.  The bean curd was yummy and I wished there was more!  It was ok, but not great.  Only $3.25 though, which can't be beat!  The lady was nice and apologetic about the veggie thing and said she hoped I liked the meal.  I tried to, but afterwards I had some fishy burps, so I wonder if something in there had been in the fish broth too.  Maybe I was just reacting to the seaweed, who knows?  The other vegetarian things they have are seaweed salad (cold), edamame, and california rolls.  I probably won't go back unless I feel like california rolls, but I'd definitely recommend this place.
author: Stacey B.

description: The nicest couple on the face of the planet runs this place.  Don't have enough cash, pay them back later.  20 cents short, not problem, that's good enough.  These people rock and are probably the only reason I keep going back.  The food is ok.  $3 for a half order of Chicken Teriyaki with salad and orange slice.  They don't take the skin off the chicken, which is kind of gross because I have to pick it off, but for $3, this half order fills me up.  Their sushi is okay, but I'd much rather have a Crazy Roll from Wasabi and Ginger.
author: Vanessa Z.

description:
From what I could tell, Yo Yo's is literally two counters, a fridge, a hot pot, and two very lovely people. You won't stay at Yo Yo's long--the speed is unbeatable--but the service is great nonetheless. As previous Yelpers have pointed out, the price is unheard of in the Financial District  ($2.55 for half-order of udon).

The only criticism I might have for Yo Yo's is the fact that the broth is most likely comprised of salt and MSG. I might also like more vegetables accompanying my salty, carb-filled treat. However, this place is still an amazing deal for the price, speed, and service. It's cold here in San Francisco and according to the newspaper headlines, none of us has any money, so Yo Yo's is a great pick!
author: Erica M.

description: This place is AWESOME for a cheap, quick, and filling lunch. Usually I just grab a half order of udon or cold/hot soba (whatever I feel like that day) and a roll and I'm good to go. And it usually comes out to under $5 which is amazing in SF. The noodle broth is flavorful and though the udon could be thicker, is very tasty. You can add in your choice of bean curd (my favorite), seaweed, and tempura flavor (gets soggy after a while though) and then add as much chili powder as you want before they close the lid. The owners are extremely friendly and efficient as well, and remember their usuals.
author: A X.

description: I am poor poor poor but love love love sushi. So with my meager paycheck in hand and a monstrous craving for something... anything sushi-esque i consulted yelp. these reviews are pretty much hit the nail on the head. i walked out with the premade smoked salmon sushi (not all that bad, stop being snobs san francisco) and some edamame and had a lovely lunch by pier two next to the Russian fishermen. Can't wait to try the infamous soup!
author: Jessica P.

description: I just moved to SF from Tokyo, where I sent many afternoons wolfing down soba for lunch. I needed my fix so I went over to Yo-Yos. For what it is, which is quick fast and cheap, its all good. I had the soba and the a roll of Takuon. The broth was good and I liked what they did with the tofu, but the noodles were too fat. Also, they didn't have any real options, just soba, udon and/or teriyaki chicken (along with a few sushi rolls). Its a good value and bang for your buck but what you pay for is what you get.
author: brandon m.

description:
Tried their hot soba with all contents and a seaweed salad.  The noodle texture is not top-notch, but the soup is quite tasty.  Overall felt a little too oily on my lips.  Maybe I will skip the tempura balls next time to see if it helps. The seaweed salad is very good too.

Just like the other said, the price is unbeatable.  My rating is more like 3.5 stars. Still have to try the terriyaki chicken and sushi next time to give a complete verdict.
author: E H.

description:
Eating my soba as I write this -- this place is awesome,  Soba is packed full of goodness (fresh tofu, dried tofu, seaweed, fishcake).  The broth is not too salty - just perfect.
The service is awesome.  

Other food - Their calamari salad is delicious.
The first time I went there I got the chicken teriyaki, which I didn't like too much, but I keep coming back for the soba.
author: alla r.

description: This is pretty good Japanese food.  It's not the highest quality of food, but what can you expect from a little shop like this one?  I had the udon and it was delicious!  I was content with my food.  I also got the seaweed salad, which was only a dollar something i think.  It came with a lot too.  For the amount you get here, it'd cost about 3-4 bucks at a regular Japanese restaurant or market.  My friend and I came here on a random day after yelping for a place to have lunch.  There isn't really a place you can sit in, so we ate at a nearby park.  YAY for sunny weather that day! hahah.  The food here is VERY recession-friendly to your wallet might I add.  4 STARS! =D
author: Lisa Z.

description: Fast and cheap noodles. Not the best, per se, but certainly a decent, quick, and inexpensive lunch.  The pre-made sushi rolls and ready-to-go edamame are also OK. You can eat like a pig for about $5.  The folks there are very nice. And they have grass jelly drink in the cold case. Mmmmmmm. Gelatinous...
author: Allyson V.

description: Further proof that cheap sushi is not good sushi.  Stick to the soups.  The soba is the best of the lot.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Yo Yo's is a gem if your work on the upper end of the Financial District. Every time I go here the couple is so nice and fast it's a pleasure. I always order the 1/2 order of the teriyaki chicken and the couple although always busy, remember me and get the order together by the time I get to the cash register. I switch between the edamame and the seaweed salad to complete the meal. How much you ask? Less than $5!!! Finding a good, quick, cheap place in the city during lunch time is always a challange and that's why I come at least once a week.
author: Thomas T.

description: Best little lunch spot in the area!  The udon is great, the sushi is excellent, the seaweed and calamari salad is divine -- and Joe and Lydia are the best folks, just the sweetest.  I'm here at least twice a week.
author: Phil H.

description:
This amazingly efficient husband and wife team consistently serve up delicious and LARGE portions of Soba/Udon Noodles in a healthy, not too oily or too salty broth for a great price ($5.50 for a quart sized container that includes the extras of tempura, seaweed, and tofu.  And if you're into portion control you can feed yourself here with a half size soba/udon for $2.25-compare that to the other soup places in the financial district!)    
They are lightning fast, but even with a line of 20 people going out the door the incredibly sweet woman finds a second to welcome her regular customers by name and calling out their regular order, all without missing a single beat.  You just can't help but want to bring your business back here again and again...and your tummy will be all for it!  You won't feel greasy or gross...just happy and satisfied!  Cash only but that probably helps them stay so fast!
The menu is posted on the wall and includes other items such as calamari salad, seaweed salad, california rolls, and chicken teriyaki.
author: Claudia K.

description: In brief: friendly, cheap, fast and tasty spot for noodles and basic sushi rolls.
author: Nikke G.

description: I'm madly in love with this place and its super cheap delicious udon
author: L C.

description: Yo Yo's has the best edamame in the city by far!  But I'd steer clear of the Unagi Roll if I was you!
author: Terika T.

description: I agree w/ the price..It's the cheapest around here ..Service here was great (in and out). I order the udon and the base soup has a lot of sugar..I felt like I was eating a candy bar...
author: Ms. Shorty s.

description: If you're broke and want to eat decent Japanese food (OOOooo and get a nice warm smile from the friendly hard-working owners) then this is the place to grab some food!  You'll be in and out of there in under 5 minutes and will have spent 5 bucks!  I usually get the half order of chicken teriyaki which is enough for me and only $3-$4! But be warned, their chicken is for the dark meat lovers only.  I don't think they believe in white meat. Anyhoo, their rolls are also decent, pre-made and ready to go when you are.  There's not place to sit, so let me suggest walking down straight down the street to the park on a warm sunny day and enjoy your meal if I may say! (Yes, I'm a dork, I know, I know).
author: Aim E.

description: I've got a love hate relationship with this place.  It is fast, cheap, and near my office.  The couple behind the counter are super friendly, but this is rarely my first choice for lunch.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
i've been deceived by yelpers!!! the star ratings are clearly only for the price.

ok, the pros: this place is dirt cheap.  i mean... getting out of here with the amount of food you get in the financial district is simply amazing.  also, it's so ridiculously fast and close to my office that one of my colleagues even commented "BACK ALREADY??!?!"  and the folks that run this place are super nice.

cons: mediocre food at its finest.  not blech... but definitely blah.  i'll gladly pay a little more for quality.
author: Steven C.

description: This place is fantastic. It's insanely inexpensive, the food is delicious and the people who run it are as nice as they come. I usually get the half order of soba, which is less than three dollars and super filling. They also sell Pocky, which doesn't hurt.
author: Liz G.

description: Great little place for fast noodles or udon. The kitsune udon was a bit sweet, but for a quick and CHEAP lunch in Jackson Square, this is the place.  I paid under $3.00 for a small udon that was quite filing and good on a chilly day. Friendly fast service. Mochi ice cream available too. I went at around 1:30 on a Friday and no line, I went around 12:30 Thursday, and the line was out the door and down the block.
author: Katherine B.

description: When you are on a tight budget and hungry as hell this is one of the best spots to go to get your fill. Where else can you go to get slightly above average teriyaki chicken with rice or somewhat decent sushi for cheap? Yo Yo's, that's where! The couple who run's this place are very sweet and nice people, yet another reason to get lunch at this place when all else fails.
author: Rommel N.

description: More like 3.5 and its definitely for the price.  Its cheap. Lunch for $5 for a half order of udon and a sushi roll.  Quality is kinda low, but i guess for the price, you have to adjust your expectations.  The tempura bits floating on top i can do without.  The broth is a little sweet but my co-worker said if you add enough of the chilly powder it would offset the sweetness.  I will try this place again tho.  Cheap is my middle name.
author: Ames K.

description: Yo let's go get some of hot udon soup yo!  I love this take out place...everything's good here.  The California Roll is yummy!  The owners always know what I want in my udon...beancurd and seaweed.  It's like she knows what every customer wants in their orders...wow!  If I'm really hungry, I'll order the teriyaki chicken.  I usually get the half order, which is just the right size.  I wish they served brown rice through...because the teriyaki sauce is so delicious that I end up eating up all the rice!!  Ughh, I can't live without carbs!!
author: Lucky M.

description: Scroll down and you'll see this place is not worth going to for sushi.  However, I will agree with the majority in saying that it is a quick fix and the half udon is your best bet.  The California rolls are also a safety net plate as they are hard to screw up.  The service is speedy quick and the owners will learn your ordering habits after going there a few times.  I wanted to give this place a 3.5 or 4, but I am suspicious that they use msg in their soups...  A nice half udon on a cold and rainy day is irresistible though!
author: Sokokyu K.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE~!  I have to come here at least twice/three times a week if not every day of the week.  It is AMAZINGLY cheap, 2 dollars for udon, 3ish for teriyaki chicken and rice with salad and the sweetest slices of oranges.
